questions.text: After suffering from a myocardial infarction, a patient was started on two drugs X and Y. The drug X inhibits the COX-1 enzyme and drug Y inhibits thrombin-induced platelet aggregation. Identify the drugs.
questions.solution:
X- Aspirin and Y- Vorapaxar are the drugs administered to the patient.

Aspirin reduces thromboxane A2 production by inhibiting the COX-1 enzyme. 

Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of PAR-1 and inhibits thrombin-induced platelet aggregation. Vorapaxar is indicated in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel to reduce thromboembolic events in patients with MI or peripheral vascular disease.

questions.text: A study was conducted among a group of 500 patients with lung cancer and another group of 300 people chosen from the general population. Both the groups were questioned about their exposure to smoking. What kind of study is this?
questions.solution:
This is a case-control study. In this scenario, 500 patients constitute the cases and 300 people from the general population constitute the controls. The study is done from effect (lung cancer) to cause (smoking).

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with hyperuricemia and delayed developmental milestones. He also has the habit of biting his lips, fingers, and feet because of which he is always strapped to the bed. Urine examined showed orange sands. Which is the most probable enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It is caused due to the complete deficiency of Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT).

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder. This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine, from which excessive amounts of uric acid is produced and excreted in urine as orange sands.

Clinical features include compulsive self-mutilation, hyperuricemia, intellectual disability, delayed milestones, dystonic movements and megaloblastic anemia.

Diagnosis is made by deficient HGPRTase enzyme activity in the erythrocyte. Partial deficiency of HGPRTase cause Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase enzyme deficiency causes urinary calculus formation with crystalluria.

Option C: Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the  2nd major cause of SCID.

Option D: Purine nucleoside phosphorylase causes a severe deficiency of T cells but B cells are normal.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is being evaluated for weakness and atrophy of distal limb musculature. Physical examination showing characteristic facies is given below. What is the mode of inheritance of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing the characteristic hatchet facies are suggestive of myotonic dystrophy (dystonia myotrophica). It is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder affecting muscle function.

There are mainly two types:

  • DM1 - In this type, the affected gene is DMPK, which codes for myotonic dystrophy protein kinase, a protein expressed predominantly in skeletal muscle. The gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 19.
  • DM2 - It is caused by a defect of the CNBP gene on chromosome 3.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the given image?

choices.text: It is associated with facial angiofibroma
They are diagnostic of a neurocutaneous syndrome

questions.solution:
The given image shows discrete tan-colored nodules over the iris called Lisch nodules (pigmented melanocytic hamartomas). They are seen in neurofibromatosis-1 (NF-1). Facial angiofibroma (adenoma sebaceum) is a feature of tuberous sclerosis (TS) and not neurofibromatosis.

The image below shows facial angiofibroma seen in tuberous sclerosis (Bourneville disease).

Lisch nodules are specifically associated with NF-1 and are usually multiple and bilateral. They are best visualized with a slit lamp examination and don’t cause any visual disturbances.

Other important ocular manifestations in NF-1 include eyelid plexiform neurofibroma, which causes S-shaped deformity of the upper lid, with a 'bag of worms' like texture, optic nerve glioma, and spheno-orbital encephalocele due to dysplasia of greater wing of the sphenoid.

NF-1 (von Recklinghausen's disease) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a loss-of-function mutation of the NF-1 gene located on chromosome 17q11.2. NF-1 produces neurofibromin, which acts as a tumor suppressor and a negative regulator of RAS-MAP kinase signaling.

Clinical features of NF-1 include café-au-lait macules, axillary freckling, Lisch nodules,  neurofibromas, and optic gliomas. 
NF-1 is more common than NF2 and typically diagnosed in childhood. NF-2 is rarer but often presents with bilateral acoustic neuroma, juvenile cataract and schwannoma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has been experiencing intermittent visual disturbances and episodes of difficulty walking over the past few months. Neurological examination reveals spasticity in the lower limbs and hyperreflexia. T2W MRI of the brain shows periventricular ovoid hyperintense lesions oriented perpendicular to lateral ventricles. Which of the radiological findings is most characteristic of this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and T2W MRI of the brain showing periventricular ovoid hyperintense lesions oriented perpendicular to lateral ventricles, called Dawson's fingers, are characteristic of multiple sclerosis. 

Multiple sclerosis(MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system characterized by inflammation, multiple demyelinating plaques, and relapsing and remitting symptoms.

It is commonly associated with paresthesia (tingling sensations), hypesthesia (numbness), optic neuritis, unilateral/ bilateral, limb weakness - spastic paralysis, Babinski's sign positive and bladder dysfunction. Optic neuritis (ON) presents as diminished visual acuity or decreased colour perception (desaturation) in the central field of vision.

MRI is used for making the diagnosis of MS due to its high sensitivity. The diagnosis of MS requires demonstrating that the lesions are disseminated in space (involving multiple areas of the brain) and in time (multiple episodes over a period of time).

The MRI below demonstrates Dawson's fingers, the demyelinating plaques through the corpus callosum, arranged at right angles along medullary veins (callososeptal location).

Other options:

Option A: A "puff of smoke appearance", derived from the Japanese term Moyamoya, is a characteristic finding on cerebral X-ray angiography in patients with Moyamoya disease. This rare, non-inflammatory, progressive, occlusive disease involves large intracranial arteries exhibiting bimodal age distribution in the first and fourth decades. Childhood moyamoya is characterised by ischemic manifestations, and adult moyamoya by hemorrhagic manifestations.

The below image shows the MR angiography findings in a patient with Moyamoya disease.

As this is a chronic condition, the lenticulostriate arteries develop a rich collateral circulation around the occlusive lesion, seen as a 'puff of smoke' (moyamoya in Japanese) on X-ray angiography as shown below: 

Option B: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal-recessive disease resulting from a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme arylsulfatase A, causing central and peripheral demyelination, ataxia, and dementia.

Symmetric confluent areas of T2 hyperintensity are seen in the periventricular white matter. Radiating T2 hypointense lines through the demyelinated deep white matter represent the sparing of the perivascular white matter. This results in the tigroid and leopard skin patterns when imaged in the long axis or cross-section, respectively. Subcortical U-fibers are spared. The below MRI shows tigroid pattern: 

Option D: Progressive supranuclear palsy is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by atrophy of structures at the midbrain-diencephalic junction (e.g., superior colliculi, red nuclei, subthalamic nuclei, and globus pallidus) and cerebellum (dentate nuclei), and mild cortical atrophy. MRI shows a hummingbird sign (atrophy of midbrain structures with a relatively intact pons region).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man admitted to ICU develops sepsis 3 days after insertion of a central venous catheter. A peripheral blood smear reveals the following. What does the structure marked by the arrow indicate?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear, prepared from an individual with bacterial sepsis, shows reactive changes in neutrophils. The arrow-marked structure is a Döhle body.

Reactive changes in neutrophils associated with leukocytosis in severe inflammatory disorders are:

  • Toxic granules, which are coarser and darker than the normal neutrophilic granules, represent abnormal azurophilic (primary) granules
  • Döhle bodies are patches of the dilated endoplasmic reticulum that appear as sky-blue cytoplasmic puddles
  • Toxic cytoplasmic vacuoles 

The image given below shows a neutrophil with cytoplasmic vacuoles.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of placental separation in stage 3 of parturition of a pregnant woman?
questions.solution:
Lengthening of the umbilical cord is seen in placental separation.

Signs of placental separation:

  • The uterus becomes globular, firm, and ballottable (earliest sign to appear)
  • Schroeder's sign - Slight rise of fundal height as the separated placenta comes down in the lower segment and uterus rests over it
  • Slight suprapubic bulging due to separated placenta distending the lower segment.
  • Kustner's sign - On pushing, the uterus cephalad with a hand on the abdomen, the cord no longer recedes
  • A sudden gush of blood
  • Permanent lengthening of cord

Note: Schroeder's ring is a constriction ring/contraction ring formed due to incoordinate uterine action.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the OPD by his wife for gasping episodes during sleep and excessive daytime sleepiness. She reported that he even dozed off while driving yesterday and nearly caused an accident. He is being treated for hypertension, gastro-oesophageal reflux, and type 2 diabetes. What else would be the ideal therapy for his symptoms?

choices.text: Implantable neuro-stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea/hypopnea syndrome (OSAHS). The ideal therapy is continuous positive airway pressure therapy (CPAP).

Option A: Supplemental oxygenation can improve oxygen saturation but there is little evidence that it improves OSAHS symptoms.

Option B: Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty is the most common surgery done in OSAHS but it is reserved for patients who cannot tolerate CPAP.

Option D: Unilateral neuro-stimulation of the hypoglossal nerve through a surgically implanted device is a recently tested therapy for OSAHS. It can be used as an alternative in selected patients who cannot tolerate CPAP.

The FDA recently authorized eXciteOSA, a new prescription-only device to reduce snoring & mild obstructive sleep apnea. This is the first device used while awake that is intended to improve tongue muscle function, which in time helps prevent the tongue from collapsing backwards and obstructing the airway during sleep.

questions.text: A 26-year-old Chinese translator presents with fever, jaundice and splenomegaly. His Hb is 6 g% and peripheral smear with brilliant cresyl blue is given below. Which of the following globin chains would you expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of extravascular hemolysis (jaundice and splenomegaly) and peripheral smear showing golf ball cells is suggestive of HBH disease. It is a type of α thalassemia where the HbH is composed of tetramers of β chains (β4).

Hb-H disease is one type of alpha-thalassaemia with inactivation of 3 of the 4 alleles. It is more common in the Asian population. It usually manifests in the 1st year of life. It causes acute episodes of hemolysis when triggered by infections or oxidant drugs.

The decreased α chain production leads to a relative excess of β chains. This leads to the formation of HbH which has a high affinity for oxygen. Such RBCs are more prone to oxidation which causes precipitation of HbH to form golf ball inclusion bodies. This leads to increased sequestration and phagocytosis in the spleen.

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles does not predominantly contain oblique fasciculi?
questions.solution:
The rectus abdominis muscle contains parallel fasciculi. The other muscles listed have oblique fasciculi. 

Muscles can be classified based on the arrangement of muscle fibers relative to the direction of pull as follows:

  • Parallel - muscle fasciculi are parallel to the line of pull. 
  • Oblique - muscle fasciculi are oblique to the line of pull. 
  • Spiral - muscle fasciculi have a spiral or twisted arrangement.

Parallel muscles can be further grouped based on their shape as follows:

  • Quadrilateral - parallel fibers run for a short distance.
  • Strap-like - parallel fibers run for a long distance.
  • Strap-like with tendinous intersections - parallel fibers are interrupted by tendinous insertions.
  • Fusiform - parallel fibers in the muscle belly that converge at the tendon region.

questions.text: Which of the following marked distances is described as the caliber of a rifled gun?
questions.solution:
The caliber of a rifled gun is described as the marked distance C in the image. Caliber is measured as the distance between two diametrically opposite lands.

It is the internal dimension of the barrel and is measured in millimeters or inches.

questions.text: A child presents with pinpoint ecchymoses around hair follicles and is not allowing anyone to move his limbs because of pain. He also has tender nodules over the chest, as seen in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing scorbutic rosary are suggestive of scurvy.

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C. Vitamin C is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline that are used in the synthesis of collagen. Hence, deficiency of vitamin C leads to the formation of defective collagen. 

Defective collagen results in capillary hemorrhages which may present as generalized bleeding tendency. It also results in defective osteoid formation. Subperiosteal hemorrhages cause acute pain and swelling mimicking acute osteomyelitis. 

Costo-chondral separation leads to the formation of tender nodules, also known as scorbutic rosary. Rickets also presents with similar nodules at the costochondral junctions known as rachitic rosary. They can be differentiated as scorbutic rosary is more sharply angulated and are painful.

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring/ Wimberger sign: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

questions.text: Which of the following is not a special derivative of tryptophan?
questions.solution:
Melanin is not a derivative of tryptophan. It is a derivative of tyrosine.

Melanin is synthesized in the melanocytes from tyrosine by the enzyme tyrosinase which converts DOPA to melanin. Copper is the co-factor of tyrosinase.

Clinical correlate: The deficiency of tyrosinase leads to albinism.

The derivatives of tryptophan are: 

  • Serotonin
  • Melatonin
  • Nicotinic acid

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: In which of the following conditions does acantholysis lead to a dilapidated brick wall appearance?
questions.solution:
Dilapidated brick wall appearance is characteristically seen in Hailey-Hailey disease.

It is an autosomal dominant disorder occurring due to a mutation in the ATP2C1 gene encoding the SERCA calcium channel ATPase. It causes blistering, particularly in the intertriginous areas.

On histology, there is a widespread loss of cohesion between suprabasal keratinocytes leading to acantholysis, which is incomplete. Hence, separated keratinocytes are still partially connected to each other giving the appearance of a dilapidated or broken brick wall, as shown in the following image.

questions.text: A baby after delivery was found to have the following finding. The mother had no antenatal care history. Which of the following defects in the intrauterine life is the cause of this condition?

choices.text: Failure of the intestinal loops to return from umbilicus
Defective closure of body wall in abdominal region
Defective closure of body wall in pelvic region
Defective closure of the vitellointestinal duct

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of gastroschisis. It is caused due to the failure of the body wall to close in the abdominal region during development.

Ventral wall defects include:

  • Gastroschisis: The intestinal loops herniate through the defect in the abdominal wall. The defect usually lies to one side of the umbilicus (right side commonly). The loops of the bowel are not covered by amnion as they herniate through the abdominal wall directly into the amniotic cavity. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid. 
  • Omphalocele: The bowel loops fail to return from the physiologic umbilical hernia. Since the umbilicus is covered by a reflection of the amnion, the omphalocele is also covered by amnion.
  • Bladder or cloacal exstrophy:  Failure of the body wall to close in the pelvic region. Bladder exstrophy is less severe of the 2 and only the bladder is exposed in this condition. Cloacal exstrophy is more severe and both the bladder and rectum, which are derived from the cloaca, are exposed. 
  • Ectopia cordis: Failure of the lateral body wall folds to close in the midline in the thoracic region. This results in the heart remaining outside the thoracic cavity.

questions.text: A chronic smoker who was recently diagnosed with COPD finally decided to quit smoking. He often thinks about stopping it but is reluctant due to the fear that he might become too irritable and restless without it. Which of the following options best describes the stage he is in?
questions.solution:
In the given scenerio, the patient is in the stage of contemplation.

The patient is aware that he has a problem, and he is thinking about changing his behaviour. He is weighing the pros and cons of behaviour modification. This is characteristic of the stage of contemplation.

Addiction recovery usually involves the following five stages

  • Precontemplation
  • Contemplation
  • Preparation
  • Action
  • Maintenance

questions.text: "Tomcat urine"  is characteristically seen in ________
questions.solution:
Tomcat urine is characteristically seen in multiple carboxylase deficiency.

It is named so because of its peculiar odour.

questions.text: A randomized control trial comparing the efficacy of two chemotherapy regimens for Hodgkin's lymphoma showed that their difference is statistically significant with p < 0.001. However, in reality the two drugs do not differ in their efficacy. What type of error is this an example of?
questions.solution:
This is an example of a type I error.

In this scenario, let us take the null hypothesis as the efficacy of two drugs being the same, which as the question states, is true in reality. The alternative hypothesis will then be that one drug is better than the other.

The questions states that p-value was found to be < 0.001, which is statistically significant and so the null hypothesis is rejected. But we already know that the null hypothesis is true and we are forced to accept the alternative hypothesis even though it is false.

When an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is called as a type I error or an alpha error or a false positive error.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl with pharyngitis complains of pain and blocked sensation in her right ear. Where does the involved structure open in the nasopharynx?

choices.text: Behind posterior end of inferior turbinate

questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a middle ear infection i.e., otitis media as a complication of pharyngitis. This is due to the spread of the infection via the eustachian tube. It opens approximately behind the posterior end of the inferior turbinate, in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx.

The eustachian tube connects the nasopharynx and the tympanic cavity in the middle ear. It is usually collapsed and opens during activities such as yawning or swallowing. Its function is to maintain the pressure in the middle ear cavity and drain any secretions from the middle ear.

questions.text: Which of the following tests identifies free and combined chlorine in water separately?
questions.solution:
Orthotolidine-arsenite test determines both free and combined chlorine in water separately.

Orthotolidine test determines free and combined chlorine together.

Chick Martin test and Garrod's test are used to test the efficacy of disinfectants.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.solution:

Note: A TB patient kit contains the full course of treatment for a single patient and thus assures the TB patient that his or her medications will be available throughout treatment. questions.text: A wet mount examination of the stool sample of a patient with abdominal pain and diarrhea is given below.  Which of the following parasites is he likely infected with?
questions.solution:
The given image showing an operculated egg (egg having a lid-like structure on its end) in the stool sample is suggestive of Fasciola hepatica infection.

The eggs of Fasciola hepatica are large, ovoid, operculated, and bile stained. They contain an immature larva (miracidium) and do not float in the saturated salt solution.

The following are the parasites with operculated eggs:

  • Fasciola hepatica
  • Fasciolopsis buski
  • Fasciola gigantica
  • Paragonimus westermani
  • Opisthorchis felineus
  • Clonorchis sinensis
  • Gastrodiscoides hominis
  • Diphyllobothrium latum

Eggs of Schistosoma japonicum, Enterobius vermicularis, and Ancylostoma duodenale are non-operculated. 

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the casualty after having suddenly collapsed while playing. Pulse is not recordable and CPR is started. After 2 minutes of CPR, the monitor shows ventricular fibrillation rhythm. What is the energy to be set for defibrillation?
questions.solution:
In a pediatric cardiac arrest, the initial energy for defibrillation is set at 2 J/kg for both monophasic and biphasic waveforms. It is increased to 4 J/kg if a second shock is required.

If a pediatric defibrillator is not available, then an adult defibrillator can be used.

In children the most common cause of cardiac arrest is asphyxia. However, a sudden witnessed collapse in a child is usually due to ventricular fibrillation.

For adult defibrillation, the energy that must be applied is

  • Monophasic defibrillator– 360 J
  • Biphasic defibrillator- 120-200 J (manufacturer recommended)

questions.text: A 26-year old athlete presented with sudden pain in her right knee after performing a heavy deadlift. On examination of the joint, swelling is present and McMurray's test is positive. X-ray appears normal. Which of the following structures is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and a positive McMurray's test indicate a meniscal injury.

In this test, the patient is made to lie in the supine position and the knee is completely flexed. One hand is used to stabilize and palpate the knee joint, while the other hand is used to internally or externally rotate the leg, depending on which meniscus is to be tested. The leg is then slowly extended. Any palpable or audible click indicates injury to the menisci.

Other tests used to detect meniscal injury include:

  • Apley's grinding test
  • Thessaly test
  • Squat test
  • Ege's test
  • Joint line tenderness test

Apley's test: In this test, the patient is made to lie in the prone position. The knee is flexed to 90º and rotated while a compression force is applied, which is called the grinding test. The reproduction of symptoms indicates a torn meniscus. The distraction test involves repeated rotation while the leg is pulled upwards by the examiner, holding the thigh down. This produces increased pain only if there is ligament damage.

Thessaly test: With the affected knee flexed to 20º and the foot placed flat on the ground, the patient bears his full weight on that leg while being supported by the examiner. The patient is then asked to twist his or her body to one side and then to the other three times. This test has shown a high diagnostic accuracy rate (95%) in detecting meniscal tears.

questions.text: A software engineer presented with complaints of dryness and itching of eyes on staring at his laptop screen. On examination, parotid swelling was noted and the test shown below was positive. The serology of this patient is likely to be positive for which of the following antibodies?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of dry eyes, parotid swelling, and a positive Schirmer test is suggestive of Sjögren's syndrome. It is associated with anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B autoantibodies.

The presence of anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B indicate extra glandular involvement and poor prognosis.

Note: Anti-Ro and anti-La in SLE indicate a good prognosis, due to decreased risk of nephritis and vasculitis.

questions.solution:
The above image shows placenta percreta as the placenta extends to the serosal edge. There is no myometrium at this site.

Accrete syndromes or morbidly adherent placenta describe the abnormally implanted, invasive or adhered placenta. This is due to:

  • Poor development of the Nitabuch layer.

questions.text: A 23-year-old lady presented to the gynecology OPD with complaints of amenorrhea and milky discharge from her breasts. Her urine pregnancy test is negative and her serum prolactin level is 175 µg/L. The resident prescribes a long-acting D2 agonist. Which of the following drugs is she likely to have been prescribed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts hyperprolactinemia. Cabergoline is a long-acting D2 agonist.

Its t1/2 is >60 hours. It is indicated for the treatment of hyperprolactinemia and acromegaly.

Bromocriptine, lisuride, and apomorphine are short-acting when compared with cabergoline.

Bromocriptine is an ergot alkaloid derivative used in the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperprolactinemia, acromegaly, and Parkinson's disease. Cabergoline is preferred over bromocriptine for hyperprolactinemia due to lower adverse effects such as nausea and also due to dosing advantage (twice a week instead of daily dosing).

Lisuride is indicated in early Parkinson's disease but is also known to decrease prolactin levels and prevent migraine attacks. Apomorphine is a morphine derivative used to treat hypomobile "off" episodes of advanced Parkinson's disease.

questions.text:
In the given image, which of the following structures are matched correctly?
  1. A-Ectocyst
  2. C-Scolex
  3. D-Brood capsules
  4. F-Endocyst
  5. H-Hydatid sand
questions.solution:
F -Endocyst and H-Hydatid sand are matched correctly.

Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Its life cycle consists of sheep and dogs as hosts. Humans are accidental hosts.

A hydatid cyst usually develops three weeks after the infection. The cyst is surrounded by a fibrous capsule called pericyst that is derived from the host tissue.

The cyst wall is composed of two layers, ectocyst (outer gelatinous membrane), and endocyst (inner germinal membrane). Ectocyst is a laminated membrane, which is acellular. It helps in the passage of nutrients. The endocyst helps in producing the laminated membrane and scoleces.

The brood capsules are cellular masses in the hydatid fluid which consists of scoleces. In a definitive host, these scoleces develop into adult tapeworm while in the intermediate hosts these develop into new hydatid cysts. The brood capsules are attached to the endocyst by a pedicle or stalk. 

The brood capsules may mature and detach from the mother cyst and become the daughter cysts, which are an exact replica of the mother cysts. The freed brood capsules and scoleces present in the hydatid fluid are called hydatid sand.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of dizziness while getting up from bed. He tells you he was recently diagnosed with BPH and has been taking prazosin. Which of the following drugs would be a good replacement for him?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of postural hypotension caused by prazosin. These symptoms can be avoided by using silodosin which has a selective antagonist action on α1A receptors over α1B receptors.

The prostate stroma has a maximum concentration of α1A receptors over other α1 receptor subtypes. α1B receptors are present on blood vessels which play a role in vasoconstriction. Hence, selective α1A receptor antagonists have minimal effect on blood pressure as compared to non-selective α1 antagonists like prazosin.

α1 receptor antagonists can be classified as:

  • Selective antagonists
    • Silodosin (α1A)
    • Tamsulosin (α1A + α1D)
  • Non-selective 
    • Prazosin
    • Terazosin
    • Doxazosin
    • Alfuzosin

questions.text: Which of the following does not follow transport saturation kinetics?
questions.solution:
Simple diffusion is not carrier-mediated transport hence do not follow saturation kinetics.

  • Facilitated diffusion, primary active transport, and secondary active transport all involve integral membrane proteins and are called carrier-mediated transport.
  • All carrier-mediated transport system follows saturation kinetics.
  • The figure shows that as the concentration of the diffusing substance increases, the rate of simple diffusion continues to increase proportionately, but in the case of facilitated diffusion, the rate of diffusion cannot rise greater than the transport maximum (Tm). Tm is analogous to the maximum velocity (Vmax) level in enzyme kinetics.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of Carrier Mediated Transport

Properties Description
Stereospecificity For example- D-Glucose is transport by facilitated diffusion but not L-isomer. Simple diffusion in contrast will not distinguish between the two.
Saturation The transport rate increases as the concentration of the solute increases until the carriers are saturated (Tm).
Competition Structurally related solutes compete for transport sites on carrier molecules.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to processus cochleariformis?
questions.solution:
Processus cochleariformis is related to the tendon of tensor tympani

Just anterior to the oval window, the medial wall presents a hook-like projection called the processus cochleariformis.

The tendon of tensor tympani takes a turn here to get the attachment to the neck of the malleus.

It is also the landmark for the 1st genu of the facial nerve and the geniculate ganglion.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with depression has improved symptomatically after initiating SSRIs. On discontinuing the drug, he became irritable and complained of insomnia, nausea, and flu-like symptoms. Which of the following drugs has the least risk of causing these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of drug discontinuation or withdrawal symptoms which are seen after sudden discontinuation of SSRIs. Fluoxetine has the least risk of causing drug-discontinuation symptoms.

Drug discontinuation symptoms of SSRIs are:

  • Nausea
  • Paresthesia
  • Flu-like symptoms
  • Insomnia
  • Irritability
  • Fatigue.

Withdrawal is least with fluoxetine as its metabolite norfluoxetine has the longest half-life. Thus the plasma level of norfluoxetine is maintained for a long time even after stopping the drug, minimizing withdrawal symptoms. Withdrawal is seen maximum with paroxetine.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with recurrent headaches. MRI shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given axial T1 MRI is suggestive of meningioma. It involves the mid-falx cerebri and is seen as a spontaneously hyperintense and homogeneously enhanced mass in the midline arising from falx.

Meningiomas are extra-axial tumours (lesions that are outside of the brain parenchyma). They are a non-glial neoplasm that originates from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges and are located anywhere that meninges are found.

Meningioma shows female predominance that may be related to the fact that some meningiomas contain estrogen and progesterone receptors. They are also associated with NF-2 gene mutation.

Typical meningiomas appear as dural-based masses isointense to grey matter on both T1 and T2 weighted imaging and demonstrate vivid contrast enhancement on both MRI and CT. CSF vascular cleft sign indicates that the mass is extra-axial. There is a cleft between the tumour and normal brain parenchyma.

The image below shows the CSF vascular cleft sign:

Dural tail sign: Refers to the linear extension of enhancement of the dura, beyond the segment on which the tumor is based. The image is an axial T1W spin-echo MRI of the brain with contrast enhancement showing dural tail (arrow) in meningioma (arrowhead).

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male in kidney failure with a serum creatinine of 2.1 mg/dl is scheduled for surgery. Which of the following muscle relaxants can be used?
  1. Succinylcholine
  2. Atracurium
  3. D-tubocurarine
  4. Cis-atracurium
  5. Pancuronium
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine, atracurium and cis-atracurium can be used in this patient who has a renal failure with elevated serum creatinine(normal value- 0.8–1.3 mg/dL in men and 0.6–1 mg/dL in women).

Succinylcholine can be safely administered to patients with diminished or absent kidney function provided serum potassium levels are normal. If the serum potassium is increased, then a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant like atracurium or cisatracurium which is non-dependent on renal excretion is to be used. Atracurium or cisatracurium undergo Hofmann elimination which is non-enzymatic spontaneous degradation.

Pancuronium is almost entirely dependent on the kidney for excretion (60–90%). Pancuronium has a prolonged elimination half-life in renal failure patients and thus should be used very cautiously.

40-60% of d-tubocurarine is excreted via the kidney and so prolonged effects are seen with renal insufficiency

 

Related Pearl: Anaesthetic drugs in patients with reduced renal function

Inhaled anaesthetics:

  • Safe- halothane, isoflurane, desflurane
  • Unsafe- methoxyflurane, enflurane, and sevoflurane

 Intravenous anaesthetics:

  • Safe- Propofol, Ultrashort acting barbiturates like thiopental, methohexital
  • Unsafe- Benzodiazepines such as diazepam

 Opioids:

  • Safe- Remifentanil> Fentanyl > Alfentanil > Sufentanil
  • Unsafe:
    • Morphine (metabolized to morphine 3/6 glucuronide which is excreted through the kidney)
    • Meperidine (metabolite normeperidine is excreted through the kidney)
    • Hydromorphone (metabolite H-3-glucuronide accumulate in renal failure patients)

 Muscle relaxants:

  • Safe- Atracurium, Cisatracurium
  • Unsafe- Rocuronium, Mivacurium

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the image below:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Morris retractor with a single, flat transversely curved blade and a blunt projecting ridge with backward projection.

Morris retractor can be single or double-bladed. It is used to retract abdominal wall incisions, loin incisions, subcostal wounds or any wounds in depth.

It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision. Thus, it is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.

Other options: 

Option A: Deaver's retractor is a question mark-shaped stout, atraumatic retractor with a broad, gently curved long blade. It is used to retract the abdominal wall and viscera. Moist mops should be kept underneath prior to placing this retractor. It is used for major abdominal surgeries, bladder surgeries and lumbar sympathectomy. 

Option C: Czerny's retractor is a superficial retractor with a thick and small blade on one side and a biflanged hook on the other side in opposite directions. It is used in hernia surgery and laparotomy, especially during closure.

Option D: Double-hook retractor consists of two hooks with a handle. It is used in excision of swellings like lipoma, neurofibroma and cyst. It is also used to hold the skin flaps when raising them.

questions.text: The following instrument is:
questions.solution:
The image is of a Ballenger swivel knife. It is used in the removal of septal cartilage in SMR (Submucosal resection) operation.

The blade of the knife revolves automatically and changes direction when cutting the cartilage anteroposteriorly downwards and posteroanteriorly. Different sizes of blades are present. It can be used to harvest septal cartilage as a graft for reconstruction.

questions.text: A 26-year-old formula one driver was rushed to the casualty, unconscious, following a heavy crash from a side-impact collision during a racing event. The CT scan was normal. However, MRI showed multiple small hemorrhages, especially in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain, with no midline shift. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a normal CT and MRI showing evidence of hemorrhages in the corpus callosum and midbrain is probably due to a diffuse axonal injury.

A diffuse axonal injury is a form of primary brain injury seen in high-energy accidents. It is caused by damage to axons throughout the brain due to rotational acceleration and then deceleration. Axons may be completely disrupted and then retract, forming axon balls.

Small hemorrhages can be seen in more severe cases, especially on MRI (investigation of choice). Hemorrhage is classically seen in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain. The prognosis is very poor.

MRI showing multiple hypointense punctate foci within the subcortical and deep white matter within the corpus callosum is characteristic of diffuse axonal injury.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Axonal Injury

The mechanism of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. This leads to the deformation of the axons by stretching them.

Pathology of DAI:

  • Changes in permeability of the axolemma
  • Axonal swelling
  • Intracellular calcium accumulation
  • Proteolysis
  • The collapse of the cytoskeleton
  • 'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours. The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and a cluster of microglial cells appears followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.
  • Immuno-histochemistry shows beta-amyloid precursor protein - the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours.

questions.text: In a patient with nephrotic syndrome, drug toxicity is least likely with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
In a patient with nephrotic syndrome, drug toxicity is least likely with morphine. 

Acidic drugs generally bind to plasma albumin while basic drugs bind to alpha-1 acid glycoprotein. Nephrotic syndrome reduces plasma albumin levels, therefore there is a decrease in the protein-bound drug fraction and an increase in the free form, resulting in drug toxicity.

This is less likely with drugs having low plasma protein binding such as morphine (only around 35%).

Efavirenz, diazepam, and valproate have a very high plasma protein binding of >90% and predominantly bind to albumin and are associated with toxicity in hypoalbuminemia.

Note: Drugs highly bound to albumin: 

  • Barbiturates
  • Benzodiazepines
  • NSAIDs
  • Valproate
  • Phenytoin
  • Warfarin

questions.text: Which of the following is not an anti-apoptotic protein?
questions.solution:
BAX and BAK are pro-apoptotic proteins.

They get inserted into the mitochondrial membrane and result in the formation of channels. This allows proteins from the inner mitochondrial membrane to leak out into the cytoplasm.

On the other hand, antiapoptotic proteins of the BCL2 family, like BCL-2 and BCL-XL limit the escape of proapoptotic mitochondrial proteins.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with pain over the forehead aggravated on bending and occasional hemoptysis. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR and red cell casts in the urine. Her serology is positive for cANCA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with cANCA positivity is suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). It is characterized by the involvement of the upper respiratory tract (sinusitis), lower respiratory tract (occasional hemoptysis), and kidneys (red cell casts).

It is a granulomatous, necrotizing vasculitis of the small vessels that mainly affects:

  • Upper respiratory tract- presenting with sinusitis, otitis media, and nasal septal perforation.
  • Lower respiratory tract- presenting with hemoptysis.
  • Kidney (glomerulonephritis)- presenting with proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension.

Apart from these organs, the disease can also affect the eye and skin. Skin lesions present as palpable purpura or subcutaneous nodules. Laboratory investigations show anemia, leucocytosis, elevated ESR, and ANCA positivity.

Options A and C: In Goodpasture's syndrome and microscopic polyangiitis, the symptoms of upper respiratory tract involvement are very rare.

Option D: Henoch-Schonlein purpura is commonly seen in children. It presents with palpable purpura, joint pain, abdominal pain, and glomerulonephritis.

Related Pearl: ANCA Antibodies

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with the following. Apple jelly nodules are seen on diascopy. Her serum angiotensin-converting enzyme levels were found to be higher than normal. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lupus pernio (cutaneous sarcoidosis) is the most likely diagnosis.

Cutaneous sarcoidosis or presents as red‐brown or red violaceous nodules or plaques, generally multiple. It is usually asymptomatic. Diascopy reveals the subtle brown‐yellow or ‘apple jelly’ color characteristic of granulomatous diseases but usually more opaque than in lupus vulgaris. At diagnosis, at least 60% of patients have an increased serum angiotensin‐converting enzyme level.

Lupus pernio is the most distinctive manifestation of cutaneous sarcoidosis. Infiltrated erythematoviolaceous plaques involve the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks, a prominent telangiectatic component is characteristic. The clinical appearance is due to the presence of epithelioid cell granulomas in the dermis.

Lupus pernio is usually painless and, as it does not tend to ulcerate, is not as mutilating as lupus vulgaris.In more than half of cases, lupus pernio is associated with sarcoidosis of the upper respiratory tract, especially in patients with involvement of the nasal rims.

It is also frequently associated with pulmonary fibrosis, chronic uveitis, and bony cysts, particularly affecting the terminal phalanges.

questions.text: Which part of the neuron contains a maximum number of Na+ channels per square micrometer?
questions.solution:
The maximum number of Na+ channels per square micrometer in myelinated neurons is present at the nodes of Ranvier. It contains 2000-12,000 channels per square micrometer.

Voltage-gated Na+ channels are highly concentrated in the nodes of Ranvier and the initial segment in myelinated neurons.

The spatial distribution of ion channels along the axon plays a key role in the initiation and regulation of action potential.

questions.text: During a rotation in the acute medical ward, you observe a patient in cardiogenic shock being started on a low-dose dopamine infusion. Which of the following would you expect to increase in this patient?
questions.solution:
At lower doses (< 2 μg/kg), dopamine only stimulates dopamine receptors in renal vasculature, causing increased urine output.

As the dose increases (2-5 μg/kg), additional cardiac stimulant action (β1) is also seen.

At very high doses (5-15 μg/kg), vasoconstriction (α1) is additionally seen.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man was rushed to the ER with right upper quadrant pain for the last 6 hours. He had been diagnosed with gallstones 10 years ago but had not undergone any treatment. Imaging revealed gallbladder wall thickening. He underwent a cholecystectomy which revealed a shrunken and nodular gallbladder with a thick wall. The following was noted on microscopy. This condition is associated with:

choices.text: Dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of chronic cholecystitis and image showing lipid-laden xanthoma cells are suggestive of xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis. This condition results due to the rupture of Rokitansky–Aschoff sinuses.

Rokitansky–Aschoff sinuses are bile-filled outpouchings of the gallbladder mucosa through the gallbladder wall. They develop in reaction to chronic inflammation of the gallbladder. Eventually, they may rupture into the wall of the gallbladder. This results in the accumulation of macrophages that have ingested biliary phospholipids, which are called xanthoma cells.

Chronic cholecystitis may have other sequelae:

  • Porcelain gallbladder - dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall
  • Hyalinizing cholecystitis - replacement of the gallbladder wall by dense fibrosis, with or without calcification (leads to higher incidence of gallbladder carcinoma)
  • Hydrops of the gallbladder - atrophic, obstructed, dilated gallbladder containing clear fluid

Acute cholecystitis includes the following variants:

  • Emphysematous cholecystitis - acute infection of the gallbladder by gas-forming organisms
  • Acalculous cholecystitis - due to gallbladder stasis and ischemia

questions.text: Four molecules of myoglobin will bind how many molecules of oxygen?
questions.solution:
4 molecules of myoglobin will bind 4 molecules of oxygen.

  • Myoglobin: This is present in skeletal muscles.
  • 1 molecule of myoglobin binds 1 molecule of O2. Thus, 4 molecules of myoglobin will bind 4 molecules of oxygen
  • The shape of O2-myoglobin dissociation curve is the rectangular hyperbola. It lies to the left of Oxygen-Hemoglobin Dissociation Curve (OHDC)(refer figure).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is posted for inguinal hernia surgery. Which is the anesthetic technique of choice in order to perform fast-track surgery on him?
questions.solution:
Infiltration anesthesia is given for fast-track surgery. 

Ambulatory/outpatient anesthesia employs the use of fast-track surgical techniques to provide adequate surgical anesthesia and minimize postoperative complications in order to reduce the duration of hospital stay.

Infiltration anesthesia (inguinal field block) is ideal to perform inguinal hernia repair because it has a lesser incidence of complications than regional or general anesthesia.

The disadvantage of infiltration anesthesia is its short duration of anesthesia even when long-acting local anesthetics like bupivacaine are used.

The flocculonodular lobe forms the vestibulocerebellum, which projects to the vestibular nuclei and is concerned with equilibrium and eye movements.

questions.text: An unidentified dead body is brought to you for autopsy. You notice a faded tattoo mark on the left arm of the body. All of the following methods would be used to visualize the same except:

choices.text: Rubbing the part and examining with a magnifying lens

questions.solution:
Ink blotting is not used to visualize tattoos.

A faded tattoo mark can be visualized by:
  • Ultraviolet light
  • Infrared photography
  • Rubbing the part and examining it with a magnifying lens

In decomposed bodies, the tattoo marks can be visualized by removing the epidermis with a moist cloth. The lymph nodes near a tattoo mark also show a deposit of the pigment.

questions.text: Which type of tubal pregnancy ruptures at a later stage?
questions.solution:
Interstitial tubal pregnancy ruptures at a later stage i.e. at 12-16 weeks. This is because pregnancy at this site is closer to the uterine myometrium which provides support as pregnancy progresses. 

Isthmic and ampullary pregnancies terminate by tubal rupture. However, isthmic pregnancy ruptures earlier. Ampullary and infundibular pregnancy can terminate by tubal abortion as well.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding dead space volume in a healthy individual?

choices.text: Anatomical dead space> physiologic dead space
Anatomical dead space< physiological dead space
Anatomical dead space and  physiologic dead space are almost equivalent
Anatomical dead space is not related to physiologic dead space

questions.solution:
In healthy individuals, anatomical dead space and physiologic dead space are almost equivalent, and can be estimated by body weight.

Dead space is the volume of the airways and lungs that do not participate in gas exchange.

Types

  • Anatomic dead space- Volume of the air-occupying conducting zone where no exchange of gases takes place.
  • Alveolar/functional dead space- the volume of gas not equilibrating with blood (wasted ventilation)
  • Total dead space/Physiological dead space = Anatomical + Alveolar dead space.

In healthy individuals:

  • Anatomical dead space = 150 mL.
  • Alveolar dead space is usually zero (increased in diseased conditions).

Hence,

  • Physiological dead space = Anatomical + Alveolar = 150 + 0 = 150 mL.
  • Physiological dead space = Anatomical dead space.
  • Radford's formula: Anatomical dead space in mL is approximately equal to the body weight in pounds.
  • Dead space can be measured by the following:
    • Single Breath N2 method (Fowler’s method)
    • Bohr’s equation

questions.solution:

questions.text: During postmortem examination of a 24-year-old man, ladder rung tears were seen in the aorta. What is the likely mechanism of the sustained injury?
questions.solution:
Ladder rung tears are multiple parallel intimal tears of the aorta, that are seen in deceleration trauma.

In these injuries, when the thorax is suddenly decelerated, the heart continues to move in the original direction. This causes severe traction on the root of the heart. This leads to ladder rung tears of the aorta. 

These may or may not be associated with a complete transection of the aorta. If death is delayed, false aneurysms and dissections may be seen.

questions.text: A patient presented for an antenatal checkup at 25 weeks of gestation. She had bilateral pitting pedal edema and a history of mild headaches. While updating her antenatal card, a weight gain of 13 kgs in the past 2 weeks was noted. USG revealed gross fetal hydrops and a hyperechoic placenta. Which of the following is not true about the patient's condition?

choices.text: It is also known as Ballantyne syndrome
Hydrops could be due to rhesus isoimmunization
It is associated with elevated liver enzymes
It is a not a form of pre-eclampsia

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of maternal mirror syndrome/Ballantyne syndrome. It may be considered a form of severe pre-eclampsia.

Maternal mirror syndrome is the association between fetal hydrops and the development of maternal edema. The syndrome is named as such because the mother mirrors the fetus. It is characterized by triple edema i.e., the fetus, mother, and placenta become edematous.

The pathogenesis of mirror syndrome, although not well established, mimics trophoblastic damage and maternal vascular endothelial dysfunction, as is also seen in pre-eclampsia. Hence, these two conditions may have a similar clinical presentation, with common features such as:

  • Edema
  • Hypertension
  • Proteinuria
  • Liver enzyme elevation
  • Headache and visual disturbances.

However, in contrast to preeclampsia, the following features are noted in maternal mirror syndrome:

  • Low maternal hematocrit i.e., hemodilution rather than hemoconcentration
  • Polyhydramnios rather than oligohydramnios
  • The fetus always shows signs of hydrops.

The etiology of fetal hydrops is not related to the development of mirror syndrome. Hydrops could be due to rhesus isoimmunization, twin-twin transfusion syndrome, congenital infections, fetal cystic hygroma, Ebstein anomaly, sacrococcygeal teratoma, vein of Galen aneurysms, etc.

In most cases with mirror syndrome, prompt delivery is indicated, because women with severe features of preeclampsia can deteriorate rapidly. In few cases, identification and treatment of the cause of fetal hydrops resulted in the resolution of symptoms for both the mother and baby for the remainder of the pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the function of an enzyme known as dicer?

choices.text: It degrades mRNA with no poly(A) tail
It trims small double-stranded RNAs into molecules that can block translation

questions.solution:
Dicer is an endonuclease that trims small double-stranded RNA into molecules that can block translation.

Dicer is an enzyme that cleaves the cytosolic dsRNA encoded by the genome and generates short, double-stranded (ds) miRNA. One of the two strands (the guide or antisense strand) selected for loading into the RNA- induced silencing complex (RISC) which is composed of one of four argonaute proteins (Ago 1→4). The RNA then forms a mature, functional 21–22 nt single-stranded miRNA.

In the RISC complex, miRNAs can modulate mRNA function by one of three mechanisms:

(1) Promoting mRNA degradation directly

(2) Stimulating CCR4/NOT complex-mediated poly(A) tail degradation

(3) Inhibition of translation by targeting the 5′-methyl cap-binding translation factor

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

questions.text: In individuals exposed to HIV, within how many hours should prophylaxis be initiated?
questions.solution: Post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV should ideally be initiated within 72 hours. It is recommended that it be started as even as early as < 2 hours.

questions.text: In what condition would you see the gallbladder as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a strawberry gallbladder. Strawberry gallbladder is seen in cholesterolosis and is associated with cholesterol stones.

Cholesterolosis is characterized by mucosal villous hyperplasia. The interior of the gallbladder resembles a strawberry. The yellow specks are aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterol esters in the lamina propria. This corresponds to the seeds of a strawberry.

Option A: Cholesterol polyposis - Cholecystography or ultrasonography shows negative shadows in a functioning gallbladder, indicating the presence of a well-defined polyp.

Options B and C: Cholecystitis glandularis proliferans/adenomyomatosis - All layers of the gallbladder wall may be thickened, but sometimes, an incomplete septum forms that separate the hyperplastic from the normal layer. Intraparietal "mixed" calculi may be present.

questions.text: Vernakalant is indicated in which of the following types of arrhythmias?
questions.solution:
Vernakalant is a newer antiarrhythmic agent indicated in atrial fibrillation.

Its mechanisms of action include:

  • Frequency and voltage-dependent block of the early and late components of the sodium current
  • The muscarinic potassium current IKACh, which is constitutively activated in atrial fibrillation is also blocked

It is indicated for rapid termination of atrial fibrillation in patients with no or minimal structural heart disease.

questions.text: Hypercalcemia is associated with all of the following medical conditions except:

questions.text: Identify the type of nerve fibre in the diagram below.
questions.solution:
In the given figure, the fiber in yellow innervates the ends of the muscle spindle. Therefore, it is a gamma motor neuron.  

Many much smaller gamma motor neurons are located in the spinal cord anterior horns (shown as the yellow efferent fiber). These gamma motor neurons average 5 micrometers in diameter, which go to small, special skeletal muscle fibers called intrafusal fibers or the muscle spindle. These fibers constitute the ends of the muscle spindle, which help control basic muscle “tone.” 

Option (b):

The alpha motor neurons (shown as the blue efferent fibre) are on an average 14 micrometers in diameter. These fibers branch many times after they enter the muscle and innervate the large skeletal muscle fibers at the motor endplate. Stimulation of a single alpha nerve fiber excites anywhere from three to several hundred skeletal muscle fibers, which are collectively called the motor unit.

Option (c):

A-beta fibers are fibers for touch and pressure.

Option (d):

A-delta fibers are fibers for pain and temperature.

questions.text: Which is the incorrect statement regarding the condition shown in the image?

choices.text: Inframammary area  and intermammary folds may be involved
TNF alpha inhibitors can be used in treatment
Obesity and smoking are associated with it
Surgery cannot be done for this condition.

questions.solution:
The given image shows hidradenitis supurativa or inverse acne. Surgical excision is the best treatment that offers a cure.

Hidradenitis suppurativa is a chronic, inflammatory, recurrent, debilitating, follicular disease that usually presents after puberty.

There are painful, deep‐seated inflamed lesions in the apocrine gland‐bearing areas of the body, most commonly the axillary, inguinal, and anogenital regions.

This definition is based on the San Francisco modification of the Dessau criteria.

The following three criteria must be met for the diagnosis to be made:

  1. Typical lesions - deep‐seated, painful nodules or ‘blind boils’; abscesses, draining sinuses, bridged scars, and paired or multiheaded open pseudocomedones in secondary lesions.
  2. Typical topography - axillae, groin, perineal and perianal region, buttocks and infra‐ and intermammary folds.
  3. Chronicity and recurrence of lesions. 

More common in young women of ages 20-29 years. Obesity and smoking are the two main factors associated with hidradenitis suppurativa.

Treatment includes: 

  • Antibiotics - tetracycline, clindamycin
  • Intralesional corticosteroids
  • Immunosuppressants
  • Acitretin
  • Anti-TNF alpha therapy
  • Surgery

questions.text: While examining the burns on this patient, you find a lack of sensation and capillary refill at the burnt site. What is the degree of burn?
questions.solution:
The characteristic features of full-thickness burns (third-degree burns) are lack of sensation in the burned skin, lack of capillary refill, and a leathery texture that is unlike normal skin.

Deep dermal and full-thickness burns require excision with skin grafting for the patient to heal the wounds properly.

questions.text: A 42-year-old obese woman is posted for a revision laparotomy surgery. She gives a history of jaundice following the previous surgery. Which drug should be avoided in her?
questions.solution:
Halothane must not be given to patients with unexplained liver dysfunction following previous anesthetic exposure due to the risk of halothane-induced hepatitis.

Halothane-induced hepatitis is immune-mediated due to antibodies against highly reactive trifluoroacetyl chloride which is a metabolite of halothane.

It is rare with an incidence of 1 per 35,000 cases but very fatal, with a mortality of 50-75%.

Risk factors for halothane hepatitis:

  • Multiple exposures to halothane at short intervals
  • Middle-aged obese women- halothane undergoes extensive metabolism in obese patients
  • Familial predisposition to halothane hepatitis

The liver in halothane hepatitis shows centrilobular necrosis.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl with a history of easy bruising was referred for further evaluation. Her previous lab reports showed that platelet count and morphology were normal. Platelet aggregations tests are given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
Agonist used Aggregation
ADP Absent
Epinephrine Absent
Collagen Absent
Ristocetin Normal
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Glanzmann thrombasthenia.

It is an abnormality of platelet GPIIb-IIIa (fibrinogen receptor). Platelets are unable to adhere to each other and to the underlying tissue of the damaged blood vessels. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. The symptoms include mucocutaneous bleeding in the neonatal period, menorrhagia, ecchymoses, epistaxis, and gingival hemorrhage.

Types of Glanzmann thrombasthenia include:

  • Type 1: Absence of GPIIb-IIIa

questions.text: A 72-year-old female presents with normal visual acuity, diminished corneal sensation, and global impairment of ocular motility of the right eye. The patient also has a severe boring headache. The MRI shows an enhancing mass within the right cavernous sinus. The pain and ophthalmoplegia respond dramatically to corticosteroid therapy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with acute ophthalmoplegia with the involvement of ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve that responds promptly to steroid therapy. The most likely diagnosis is Tolosa-Hunt syndrome.

It is an idiopathic, sterile inflammation that primarily affects the cavernous sinus. It is characterized by painful acute ophthalmoplegia with or without the involvement of the optic nerve and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.

The pain is described as gnawing or boring and may precede ophthalmoplegia.

The inflammation and pain in patients typically responds rapidly and dramatically to corticosteroid therapy. However, it is a diagnosis of exclusion.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with migratory arthralgia and a malar skin rash that is exacerbated by sun exposure. Her urinalysis shows moderate proteinuria and red blood cell casts and she had leucopenia. Serum auto-antibodies with high specificity for this patient’s condition react with which of the following?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is consistent with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The autoantibodies (anti-ds-DNA) react with double-stranded DNA.

SLE is an autoimmune disease involving multiple organs, characterized by a vast array of autoantibodies, particularly antinuclear antibodies (ANAs). The injury is caused mainly by the deposition of immune complexes and the binding of antibodies to various cells and tissues.

Option A: Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are specific for primary biliary cirrhosis.

Option B: Rheumatoid factor is an IgM antibody directed against the Fc fragment of self-IgG. It is found in patients with rheumatoid arthritis and other collagen tissue disorders.

Option C: Anti-centromere antibodies are present in the majority of patients with CREST syndrome.

questions.text: An upper GI series of a patient being evaluated for difficulty in swallowing is given below. It is suggestive of which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
The given upper GI series shows the collection of contrast in a posterior pharyngeal pouch-like structure, which favors the diagnosis of Zenker's diverticulum.

A barium swallow study may show a diverticulum arising from the midline of the posterior wall of the distal pharynx near the pharyngoesophageal junction. The diverticulum is typically noted at the C5-6 level. The outpouching may be transient, sometimes referred to as a pharyngeal pouch. The pouch is best identified during swallowing and is best visualized on the lateral view. 

Since a majority of patients with a Zenker's diverticulum have a hiatal hernia and gastro-oesophageal reflux, the distal esophagus should also be evaluated.

Note: Killian–Jamieson diverticulum is an outpouching from the lateral wall of the proximal cervical esophagus. 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

Related Pearl: Barium swallow
