Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with limbal scar presents to the ophthalmology clinic with marked defects in both near and far vision. Clinical examination reveals a wide and deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, and a dark pupillary reflex. A vision of 6/6 is achieved with correcting lens of +11D. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A limbal scar with defective near and distant vision, a wide and deep anterior chamber, iridodonesis, and dark pupillary reflex suggests aphakia.

Aphakia is the condition in which the lens is absent from the pupillary area. Signs of surgical aphakia include limbal scar, deeper anterior chamber than normal, iridodonesis (tremulousness of the iris), jet black color of the pupil. On Purkinje's test, only the first and second images are seen. A small disc is seen on fundus examination and high hypermetropia is seen on retinoscopy. 

The best treatment option is secondary intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with a history of chronic alcoholism presented with increasing abdominal girth and malaise. On examination, shifting dullness was present and the liver span was 6 cm. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease. In this condition, there are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions called Mallory Denk bodies. They are composed of intermediate keratin filaments.

Mallory bodies are also seen in the following conditions:

  • Morbid obesity
  • Indian childhood cirrhosis
  • Wilson’s disease
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis

There are several types of cytoskeletal proteins such as microtubules, thin actin filaments, thick myosin filaments, and intermediate filaments (10 nm).

The intermediate filaments provide a flexible intracellular scaffold that organizes the cytoplasm and resists the forces applied to the cell.

They are divided into five classes: 

  • Keratin filaments - characteristic of epithelial cells (forms Mallory Denk bodies)
  • Neurofilaments - neurons (forms neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease)
  • Desmin filaments - muscle cells
  • Vimentin filaments - connective tissue cells
  • Glial filaments - astrocytes

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a persistent headache for the past few months. On evaluation, her vision on Snellen's chart was 6/6 in both eyes. The fundus also appears to be normal. Visual field charting shows a bitemporal visual field defect. Site of the lesion is _________
questions.solution:
The site of the lesion is optic chiasma. Lesions at the chiasma characteristically produce bitemporal field defects due to the decussation of nasal fibres.

In retrochiasmal lesions, homonymous hemianopia is seen. Further, in cortical lesions, macular (central) vision is spared.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: What is the percentage of cytosine in DNA if the percentage of thymine residues is 28%?
questions.solution:
The percentage of cytosine in DNA will be 22%.

According to Chargaff's rule in cellular DNA, regardless of species,
A = T and G = C
Purines = Pyrimidines i.e. A+G = C+T.

In the question it is given that thymine is 28%, therefore adenine is also 28%. So, adenine + thymine = 56% and guanine + cytosine = 44%. Since guanine = cytosine, the percentage of cytosine = 44/2 = 22%.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease came with complaints of vomiting and diarrhea. His blood gas reports show pH = 7.40, HCO3- = 23 mEq/L, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, Cl- = 100 mEq/L. What is your probable diagnosis?

choices.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) with metabolic alkalosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: The pH being 7.4 is within normal limits.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 23 mEq/L and again is within normal limits.

At this juncture, we have ruled out options B and C as this particular clinical scenario is not suggestive of a simple acid-base disorder.

Step 3: Calculating the Anion gap:

  Anion gap = [Na+] – ([Cl-] + [HCO3-])

                   = 145-(100+23)

                   = 22 mEq/L

The presence of a high anion gap indicates that there's indeed an acid-base disorder, thus ruling out option A.

A high anion gap indicates metabolic acidosis. However, HCO3- levels within normal limits suggest that there is also coexisting metabolic alkalosis in this patient.

This can be confirmed by calculating the delta gap.

Delta gap = ΔAG - ΔHCO3-

In this scenario: Delta gap = (22-10) - (24-23) = 11 mEq/L

Delta gap is > +6 suggesting the presence of metabolic alkalosis along with HAGMA.

If the delta gap is significantly positive (>+6), metabolic alkalosis is present because the rise in the anion gap is more than the fall in bicarbonate. If the delta gap is significantly negative (<6) then hyperchloremic acidosis is usually present because a rise in the anion gap is less than a fall in bicarbonate.

Alternatively, this can be confirmed by calculating the delta ratio.

Delta ratio = the increase in Anion Gap / the decrease in HCO3-

It is used in the presence of a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), to check it is a ‘pure’ HAGMA or if there is coexistant normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) or metabolic alkalosis.

Delta ratio values:

  • 1-2 indicates HAGMA
  • < 1 indicates NAGMA + HAGMA
  • > 2 indicates HAGMA + Metabolic alkalosis

In this scenario,

Delta ratio = 12/1 = 12

Thus, the acid-base disorder for the above scenario is HAGMA with metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: 10 g of inulin is injected IV and after equilibrium the concentration of inulin in plasma is 50mg/100ml. If 10% of the inulin is excreted, what is the ECF volume?
questions.solution:
Inulin is the indicator used to measure the ECF volume. (Since, inulin can cross blood vessel but not cell wall)

Calculation:

  • Since 10% is excreted, volume of inulin excreted is 1 gm. The amount of inulin diluted in ECF is 9 g ( 10 - 1) i.e, 9000mg is present in x 

    From the given values, 50 mg is present in 100ml, which can be re-written as

     

              50/100 =  9000/x

                    x = 9000 * 100 / 50 

                  = 9000 * 2

                   = 18,000mL

                   = 18L

Second method : 

  • Since 10% is excreted, volume of inulin excreted is 1 gm. 
  • Amount injected = 10g
  • Amount excreted = 1g

Now, the concentration of inulin after equilibrium is 50 mg/100ml which is equal to 0.05 g/100ml. (Convert the values into same units).

Therefore, ECF volume = (10-1)*100/0.05 =18000ml = 18 L

questions.text: An outbreak of guinea worm disease was reported among villagers who used step wells for drinking water. In order to arrest the spread of disease, a decision was made to replace step wells with sanitary and safe wells. All of the following measures would be considered during its construction except:

choices.text: Must be located at least 15 metres away from sources of contamination
A partition space for washing clothes and vessels
Lining must be made to a depth of 6 metres or more
Hand-pump must be made to handle rough use

questions.solution:
Washing clothes, vessels, and bathing must be prohibited around wells to avoid contamination of the water.

Step wells are a type of pucca wells which enable people to descend into the well to fetch water. It is obsolete now, as there is considerable personal contact between the user and the water which can pose a health hazard to the community.

Related Pearl: Wells

  • Wells are a source of ground water and are widely used across India.
  • The two main types of wells are the shallow and deep wells, the difference between which are:
  Shallow Wells Deep Wells
Description They tap subsoil water, i.e., water from above the first impervious layer in the ground They tap water from the water-bearing stratum which is below the first impervious layer of the ground
Chemical quality Moderately hard water Very hard water
Contamination Very often grossly contaminated and liable to pollution Low contamination levels and purer than water from shallow wells
Yield Generally dry in summer Provides constant water supply
Prevalence in India Very common Less common than shallow wells
  • An artesian well is a type of deep well in which the water rises to the surface due to the pressure with which it is held between two impervious/impermeable layers. There is no pump or other manual methods needed to bring the water to the surface. These are not common in India.
  • Wells can also be classified according to the method of construction as dug wells and tube wells.

i) Dug wells:

  • They are the most common type of wells in India.
  • In rural India, two types of dug wells exist, namely the unlined katcha wells and the masonry or pucca wells.
  • The katcha wells are just big holes dug into the sand.
  • The pucca wells are well built with walls or linings made of brick or stones.
  • Step wells are types of pucca dug wells that have steps. These steps can be used by people to descend into the well and come in contact with water. This increases the risk of water contamination.

ii) Tube wells:

  • Shallow tube wells are also called driven wells and deep tube wells are called bore wells.
  • They are safer sources of water compared to other wells, relatively cheaper to build and maintain.
  • Tube wells use strainers at the bottom and hand pumps at the top attached by a pipe in between.

The following are the considerations for building a safe and sanitary well:

Location Must be at least 15 m away from sources of contamination. Must not be >100 m from households.
Lining Must be made of brick or stones set in cement to a depth of 6 m, so that water enters from bottom and not sides. Height of lining above ground level must be 60 – 90 cm.
Parapet Wall Must be at least 70 – 75 cm (28 inches) from the ground level.
Platform Should stretch at least 1 m around the well in all directions.
Drain It should be a pucca drain to carry spilled water to a public drain beyond the cone of filtration of the well.
Covering There should be a cement concrete covering over the well.
Hand-pump Should be able to withstand rough handling.
Consumer responsibility Consumers must practice basic precautions before handling the well.
Quality The water standards in terms of quality must be conformed to.

questions.text: According to the American college of obstetricians, macrosomia is defined as the fetal birth weight of______.
questions.solution:
According to the American college of obstetricians (ACOG), macrosomia is defined as the fetal birth weight of ≥ 4.5 kg.

Macrosomia refers to growth beyond a specific threshold, regardless of gestational age. In developed countries, the most commonly used threshold is the weight above 4.5 kg, but weight above 4 kg is also commonly used.

The WHO defines the cut-off at 4.0 kg for fetal macrosomia in its guidelines for the management of common maternal conditions. This is followed in India.

questions.text: All of the following agents act by intracellular receptors except ______
questions.solution:
Insulin receptors belong to the class of trans-membrane enzyme-linked receptors.

Transmembrane enzyme-linked receptors consist of a large extracellular ligand-binding domain. It is connected to an intracellular subunit having enzymatic property through a single transmembrane helical peptide chain. The enzyme on the cytosolic side is usually a protein kinase (tyrosine) or membrane-bound GC (guanylyl cyclase).

Physiological ligands for transmembrane enzyme-linked receptors are mostly growth factors and chemokines. Other receptors belonging to this class include:

  • Receptor tyrosine kinases - Growth factors (PDGF, EGF, VEGF); insulin
  • Membrane-bound GC - Natriuretic peptides
  • Receptor serine-threonine kinases - TGF-β

questions.text: Arthus reaction is caused by which of the following process?
questions.solution:
Arthus reaction is characterized by a localized area of tissue necrosis due to immune-complex-mediated (type III hypersensitivity reaction) vasculitis in the skin.

This reaction can be produced experimentally by intracutaneous injection of antigen in a previously immunised animal that contains circulating antibodies against the antigen. As the antigen diffuses into the vessel wall, it binds with the preformed antibody, and immune complexes are formed locally. These complexes precipitate in the vessel walls and cause fibrinoid necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective parenteral iron preparation prescribed for postpartum women with iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
Ferric carboxymaltose is considered superior to all other parenteral iron supplementation especially for iron deficiency anemia in postpartum women.

Ferric carboxymaltose (FCM) is a dextran-free IV iron preparation. It allows rapid administration of high doses of iron (up to 1000 mg iron in 15 min).

It is safe and effective in improving the mean Hb level. It avoids the need for blood transfusions.

questions.text: Which of the following phospholipids is found only in the mitochondria and helps in the mitochondrial function?
questions.solution:
Cardiolipin is the phospholipid found only in the mitochondria. 

Cardiolipin is an important component of the inner mitochondrial membrane. It is essential for the optimal function of numerous mitochondrial enzymes involved in mitochondrial energy metabolism and for the maintenance of the mitochondrial membrane structure. 

Decreased cardiolipin or alteration in its metabolism results in mitochondrial dysfunction. This is seen in Barth syndrome (cardioskeletal myopathy) which is characterized by an enlarged and weakened heart (dilated cardiomyopathy), weakness in muscles used for movement (skeletal myopathy), recurrent infections due to small numbers of white blood cells (neutropenia), and short stature.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Paget's disease. X-ray of the patient is given below. In which phase of the disease is the patient at?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows blade of grass deformity seen in the osteolytic phase of Paget's disease.

An initial osteolytic phase involves prominent bone resorption and marked hypervascularization. Radiographically, this manifests as an advancing lytic wedge or blade of grass or flame shaped lesion.

The second phase is a period of very active bone formation and resorption. It is characterised by normal lamellar bone replaced with haphazard (woven) bone.

In the final sclerotic phase, bone resorption declines progressively and leads to a hard, dense, less vascular mosaic bone, which represents the so-called burned-out phase of Paget’s disease.

The arrow mark in the following image indicates blade of grass appearance.

questions.text: The distribution of intraocular pressure (IOP) in 100 glaucoma patients form a normal distribution curve. It has a mean of 30 mm of Hg with a standard deviation (SD) of 1 mm of Hg. 97.5% of patients would have an IOP more than what value?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, 97.5% of patients would have an IOP of more than 28 mm of Hg.

The mean IOP is 30mm of Hg and SD is 1.0 mm of Hg. According to the empirical rule of the normal distribution, 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean, i.e., mean ± 2 SD. So 95% of patients will have their IOP between 30 ± 2 = 28 to 32 mm of Hg. 

Out of the remaining 5%, half will have IOP < 28 and the other half will have > 32. So half of 5%= 2.5% has IOP <28mm Hg. Thus the remaining 97.5% has IOP > 28mm of Hg.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: A psychologist gives the following card to a patient and asks him to describe what he sees. Which of the following is being assessed here?
questions.solution:
The picture given is of Rorschach's inkblot test, which is a projective personality test that focuses on the unconscious aspects of personality.

Projective tests are based on the principle that when presented with an ambiguous stimulus, such as an inkblot or an image, the patient's responses will reflect fundamental aspects of his or her personality. The ambiguous stimulus is a screen on which the individual projects his or her own needs, thoughts, or conflicts.

Commonly used projective tests are:

  • Thematic apperception test
  • Rorschach's inkblot test
  • Sentence completion test
  • Draw a person test

In Rorschach's inkblot test, 10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblots are shown to the participants. The test is administered in two phases:

  • Free association phase- participant's response to the cards is recorded
  • Inquiry phase- participants explain why they formed the impression.

Related Pearl: Personality tests

questions.text: Below is a diagram depicting the natural history of the disease. Which point marks the onset of symptoms?
questions.solution:
Point C represents a point where signs and symptoms appear.

Various points marked in the image represent the following:

Point A: Entry of infectious agent into the host.

Point B: Pathological and physiological changes occur in the stage of the subclinical phase. These changes are induced by the causative agent but are not sufficient enough to cause clinical signs and symptoms.

Point C: Marks onset of clinical signs and symptoms.

Point D: Usual time of diagnosis at which clinical signs and symptoms are well evident.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. She is a known case of ovarian cancer. The following finding was noted on examination. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows upper eyelid lilac erythema or heliotrope rash. The given clinical presentation of proximal myopathy with the characteristic heliotrope rash and history of an internal malignancy point towards a diagnosis of dermatomyositis.

Classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids. Pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.
  • V sign- confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
  • Shawl sign- confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
  • Gottron’s papules- erythematous papules and plaques over the extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints. Pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.
  • Gottron's sign- erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles
  • Mechanic’s hands- rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Facial rash- confluent erythema in the malar distribution involving the cheeks, nasal bridge, and nasolabial folds
  • Nail fold changes
  • Flagellate erythema- linear erythema on the upper back with pruritus
  • Poikiloderma- mottled pattern of hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules with telangiectasias
  • Cutaneous calcinosis- accumulation of calcium deposits in the skin

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the OPD with right-sided facial weakness. On examination, she has vesicles in the external auditory canal and over the tympanic membrane. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of facial paralysis along with vesicular eruptions in the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane is suggestive of Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus).

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is caused by the reactivation of Herpes zoster in the geniculate ganglion. In most patients, there is an involvement of the trunk of the facial nerve, which results in severe facial palsy. 

Often, the 8th cranial nerve is also involved, which causes hearing loss and vertigo. There may also be anesthesia of the face due to the involvement of the 5th cranial nerve.

 

Bell's palsy is an idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset due to a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve.

 

Moebius syndrome is a congenital unilateral/bilateral lower motor neuron facial nerve paralysis with abducens palsy causing limited ocular abduction.

Melkersson syndrome is an idiopathic disorder consisting of a triad of:

  1. Facial paralysis
  2. Swelling of lips
  3. Fissured tongue.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient with a history of chronic arthritis on treatment came with complaints of defective vision in both eyes. On examination, vision in RE = 6/12, LE = 6/18, IOP = 18 mmHg in both eyes, the anterior segment was normal, fundus examination and fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) findings given in the figure. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical viginette of female patient on treatment for chronic arthritis which is most likely the drug chloroquine given for rheumatoid arthritis, now presenting with decreased visual acuity, fundoscopy with a typical bull's eye sign and Fundus fluroscein angiography showing increased fluroscence in the macular area is suggestive of chloroquine toxicity.

Chloroquine and it's derivative hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) are antimalarial drugs which is also used to treat connective tissue disorders such as Rheumatoid arthritis, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) and Discoid Lupus.

The maximum dose allowed for chloroquine is 6 mg/kg in 24 hours while for hydroxychloroquine it is 4.5 mg/kg. Hydroxychloroquine has a lower risk of ocular toxicity and hence is percived to be a safer drug but with weaker anti-inflammatory effect.

Manifestations of Chloroquine toxicity:

  • Reversible on stopping the drug: difficulty in night vision, blurring of vision, diplopia, keratopathy
  • Central and paracentral scotomas
  • Earliest fundus findings: blunting of foveal reflex, irregularity in the macular pigmentation.
  • Advanced stages: 'Bull's eye maculopathy' where the central irregular pigmentation may become surrounded by a concentric zone of hypopigmentation
  • End-stage appearance includes bullseye maculopathy, pigmentary degeneration of retina and bone spicule formation, vascular attenuation, and optic atropy.

Screening should include a baseline examination for all patients before starting these drugs followed by annual screening starting after 5 years of use.

Pre-existing maculopathy is considered a contraindication to treatment with chloroquine and HCQ because underlying abnormalities may mask early toxicity.

Screening examinations include visual acuity testing, dilated fundus examination, spectral-domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT) testing, and functional assessment with Humphrey test.

Various causes of Bull's eye maculopathy are:

  1. Chloroquine and HCQ toxicity
  2. Cone-Rod dystrophy
  3. Advanced stargardt's disease
  4. Clofazimine retinopathy

questions.text: Fractalkine belongs to which chemokine family?
questions.solution:
Fractalkine is the only known member of the CX3C chemokine group.

CX3C chemokines contain 3 amino acids between the 2 cysteines.

This chemokine exists in two forms:

  • Cell surface-bound protein -
    • Induced on endothelial cells by inflammatory cytokines
    • Promotes the strong adhesion of monocytes and T cells
  • Soluble form -
    • Derived by proteolysis of the membrane-bound protein
    • Potent chemoattractant activity for the same cell.

questions.text: What are the cardinal movements of labour?
questions.solution:
The cardinal movements of labour are engagement, descent, flexion, internal rotation, extension, external rotation, expulsion.

(Mnemonic: Every Day FIRE Raises Extremely)

  • Every: Engagement
  • Day: Descent
  • F: Flexion
  • IR: Internal rotation
  • E: Extension
  • Raises: external Rotation
  • Extremely: Expulsion

The most common presentation is cephalic and presenting part is vertex. Head enters the pelvis through transverse diameter majorly and left occipito transverse is the commonest fetal position. Internal rotation of fetal head occurs at the level of ischial spine. In a vertex delivery, the baby's head is delivered by extension and in a breech delivery, the baby's head is delivered by flexion. The best time to give episotomy is after crowning has occured.

questions.text: What is the area from which water drains into impounding reservoirs known as?
questions.solution:
The area draining into the impounding reservoirs are known as catchment areas.

Impounding reservoirs are also called embankment ponds. These reservoirs are artificial lake-like water bodies. They are made by building an embankment or earth fill in an area into which natural water flows and can be stored for usage. Dams are also built to create these reservoirs.

Water from these reservoirs is second in purity to rainwater but is not completely free from impurities. Catchment areas are the main sources of impurities in the water in impounding reservoirs.

questions.text: The following spot film was taken while performing a voiding cystourethrogram for a 2-year-old girl. Which of the following investigations will be useful for the evaluation of renal scarring in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) shows a unilateral grade 4 vesicoureteric reflux (VUR). The investigation of choice to evaluate for renal scarring in reflux nephropathy is the Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) scan.

It is used in renal imaging to evaluate renal structure and morphology, particularly in paediatric imaging for the detection of scarring and pyelonephritis. DMSA is an ideal agent for the assessment of the renal cortex as it binds within the proximal tubules of the cortex with longer retention than other agents.

It allows a better assessment of differential renal function. It is a static scan as opposed to dynamic DTPA or MAG3 scans. Other common renal scans include:

  • Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) - used for direct measurement of GFR as it is cleared only via glomeruli with no tubular excretion (option B). 
  • Tc-99m MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) - excreted through the renal route via both glomeruli infiltration and tubular excretion. Hence, in pediatric patients and patients with poor renal function, this test is considered superior to a DTPA scan. (option C).
  • In renovascular hypertension, captopril DTPA is used for screening and the gold standard investigation is renal angiography.

The following image shows a DMSA scan of a patient with renal failure with reduced uptake in both kidneys.

questions.text: Which of the following is an unlikely complication in patients with bronchiectasis?
questions.solution:
Lung cancer is not a known complication of bronchiectasis.

Complications of bronchiectasis include:

  • Massive hemoptysis 
  • Empyema and lung abscess
  • Respiratory failure
  • Pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale
  • Secondary amyloidosis (AA type)

Chronic and recurrent infections lead to secondary amyloidosis (AA type) and involve the kidneys.

questions.text: A female baby born at 30 weeks of gestation was admitted to NICU for prematurity and respiratory distress. She was placed on CPAP and enteric feeds were started. On day 5 of admission, she became lethargic and there was distension of the abdomen. A plain radiograph of the abdomen shows the following findings. Which statement about the condition is false?

choices.text: Antenatal steroids have shown to reduce the occurrence of this condition
Modified Bell's staging can be used for this condition
Surgery is the treatment of choice for all stages

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and radiological findings are indicative of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). The absolute indication for operative management of NEC is the presence of intestinal perforation. Milder cases can be treated with gut rest, antibiotics, and parenteral nutrition. 

The radiograph shows the presence of multiple air bubbles within the bowel wall. This is called pneumatosis intestinalis and is a pathognomonic sign suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis. 

Necrotizing enterocolitis is the necrosis of a portion of the bowel and is the most common gastrointestinal surgical emergency in the neonatal period. The single most important risk factor is prematurity. Other contributing factors are enteral feeding, ischemia, and infection. Administration of antenatal steroids is known to reduce the occurrence of NEC.

It usually occurs in the first few days of life after the initiation of the enteral feeds. Some clinical features include:

  • Lethargy
  • Feeding intolerance
  • Bloody stools
  • Abdominal distension
  • Abdominal tenderness.

The radiograph may show pneumatosis intestinalis, portal venous gas, ascites, and the presence of free air.

The modified Bell's criteria is used for staging the severity of NEC.

questions.text: The findings associated with abetalipoproteinemia are :
questions.solution:
Figure A shows vacuoles (unabsorbed fat) in the cytoplasm of the enterocytes. Figure B shows acanthocytes. These findings are associated with abetalipoproteinemia. 

Figure C shows distended macrophages in the lamina propria and periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive granules as seen in Whipple's disease.

Acanthocytes are abnormal red blood cells with spiked cell membranes due to thorn-like projections. Causes of acanthocytes in peripheral smear are:

  • Abetalipoproteinemia 
  • Renal disease
  • Liver disease
  • Hemolytic anemia

questions.text: Phases of the ventricular muscle action potential are shown below. At which phase of the below image, the action potential is most dependant on sodium permeability?
questions.solution:
The action potential is most dependant on sodium permeability in phase 0. 

Action potential of myocardium:

  • Phase 0: Depolarisation: Influx of Na+ into myocyte.
  • Phase 1: Early repolarization: Efflux of K+ from myocyte.
  • Phase 2: Plateau: Ca2+ enters myocardial cells via voltage regulated L-type Ca2+ channels.
  • Phase 3: Repolarisation: Efflux of K+.
  • Phase 4: Restoration of RMP: Restoration of Na+ and K+ by Na-K ATPase.

questions.text: A 35-year-old immunocompromised patient presented with fever, headache, and neurological deficits. MRI showed multiple enhancing lesions and a stereotactic biopsy of the lesion was done. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows lymphocytes, macrophages and eosinophils surrounding the toxoplasma bradyzoites encased in cysts. Along with the case scenario, the most likely diagnosis is cerebral toxoplasmosis.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection commonly found in the setting of HIV-associated immunosuppression. Toxoplasmosis of the CNS produces brain abscesses, which are found most often in the cerebral cortex (near the grey-white junction) and deep gray nuclei.

Lesions of acute cerebral toxoplasmosis exhibit central necrosis, petechial haemorrhages surrounded by acute and chronic inflammation, macrophage infiltration, and vascular proliferation. Both free tachyzoites and encysted bradyzoites may be found at the periphery of the necrotic foci. Chronic lesions consist of small cystic spaces containing scattered lipid and hemosiderin-laden macrophages that are surrounded by gliotic brain.

Option A: In cerebral malaria caused by P. falciparum, brain vessels are plugged with parasitized red cells. Around the vessels, ring hemorrhages and small focal inflammatory reactions (called malarial or Dürck granulomata) are seen.

Option C: Herpes simplex encephalitis is necrotizing and often hemorrhagic. Cowdry type A intranuclear viral inclusion bodies may be found in both neurons and glia.

Option D: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is an encephalitis caused by the JC polyomavirus. The disease occurs almost exclusively in immunosuppressed individuals. The virus preferentially infects oligodendrocytes and hence demyelin­ation is its principal pathologic effect. The enlarged oligodendrocyte nuclei contain glassy amphophilic viral inclusions.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with fever and breathlessness for a month. Chest radiograph shows patchy infiltration in the lower lobes bilaterally and the lung biopsy shows the following finding. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Fever, breathlessness with bilateral lower lobe patchy infiltration and Owl's eye inclusion bodies on lung biopsy suggest a diagnosis of pneumonia caused by cytomegalovirus (CMV).

CMV is a herpesvirus. It causes congenital infection in neonates, heterophile antibody-negative infectious mononucleosis-like syndrome in children and adults, and systemic infections (pneumonia, colitis) in immunocompromised patients. Diagnosis is made by PCR. When cultured, infected cells show owl’s eye inclusion bodies, which are intranuclear basophilic inclusion bodies.

questions.text: A cross-sectional view of a skeletal muscle fiber through the H zone would reveal the presence of  _______
questions.solution:
H zone is the central region of the A band which is lighter than the outer edges of the A band because the H zone is occupied by thick filaments only (No cross bridges)

In the figure, note the section through various levels and the myofilaments observed.

  • Section through I band → only actin (thin filament)
  • Section through A band (Exlcuding H zone) → Actin and Myosin
  • Section through H zone → only myosin (thick filament)
  • Section through M line → thick filament linked with accessory proteins
  • Section at AI junction → both actin and myosin

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: Where does the Heuser’s membrane develop from?
questions.solution:
Heuser's membrane or exocoelomic membrane develops from flattened cells derived from the hypoblast. 

On day 9-10 of pre-embryonic development, flattened cells from the hypoblast begin to migrate to the abembryonic pole. They form a layer of cells just beneath the cytotrophoblast. This layer is called the Heuser's membrane. Once the blastocyst cavity is fully lined with Heuser's membrane, it is called the exocoelomic cavity.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is brought to the emergency department in a state of unconsciousness. Her BP is 70/50 mm of Hg. Her ECG is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes an unconscious patient, who is hemodynamically unstable (systolic BP <90 mmHg or mean arterial pressure <65 mmHg). The ECG shows a narrow QRS complex tachycardia (heart rate of 188 BPM) with regular RR interval and absent P waves, characteristic of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). The next step in management is QRS-synchronized DC cardioversion.

Shown below is the algorithm for the management of supraventricular tachycardia:

Options A, B, and C are all used in stable cases. Vagal maneuvers like carotid massage or Valsalva are tried first followed by IV Adenosine. If these are ineffective, IV Verapamil, Diltiazem, or Beta blockers are used.

questions.text: Which disease is transmitted by the  following vector that is found in cracks and crevices of walls in the day time?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a sandfly. It transmits visceral leishmaniasis.

Note: Sandfly acts as a vector for the following diseases:

  • Kala-azar
  • Oriental sore
  • Sandfly fever
  • Oroya fever

Japanese encephalitis is transmitted by the Culex mosquito. Dengue is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito.

Trypanosomiasis is transmitted by the tsetse fly.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: Inspiratory stridor is found in what kind of lesions:
questions.solution:
Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.

Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi such as bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea like laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

Stridor is an audible respiratory noise that gets produced by turbulent airflow through an obstructed upper airway. It is an inspiratory sound that may have an expiratory component. It is distinct from stertor which is a snoring-like noise produced from an obstructed nasopharynx or oropharynx. 

The intensity and pitch of sounds originating from the respiratory system vary based on their site of origin within the respiratory tract and may be heard with or without a stethoscope. Usually, the pitch of the sound increases, and the intensity decreases as one goes lower into the respiratory tract.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient from Bihar comes with complaints of hypopigmented macules over the trunk and face. The nerves and sensations are found to be normal and there is no visible scaling. The patient gives a history of prolonged fever 2 years back for which he was treated. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The case scenario suggests a diagnosis of post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis. The drug of choice for this condition is miltefosine. 

Approach to the case: 

The patient hails from a kala-azar endemic zone—Bihar. The rash appears 1-2 years after a history of prolonged fever, which suggests visceral leishmaniasis. There are 2 other differentials—leprosy and tinea versicolor. 

  • The presence of hypopigmented macules over the trunk and face, suggests a differential of leprosy, but the nerves and sensations are normal, hence ruling it out.
  • There is no scaling visible in the lesions, ruling out tinea versicolor. 

In kala-azar, after a variable period of years or months, diffuse nodulation begins to develop in these macules. The rash is progressive over many years and seldom heals spontaneously. As it may persist for up to 20 years, these patients may act as a chronic reservoir of infection.

The image below shows post-kala-azar cutaneous leishmaniasis. 

Although studies say that miltefosine is the drug of choice for the treatment of PKDL, according to the Kala-azar Elimination Program, the preferred order of drugs to treat PKDL:

 (i) Liposomal amphotericin B > (ii) Miltefosine > (iii) Amphotericin B deoxycholate

Since miltefosine is strongly contraindicated in pregnancy, it is not preferred as the first choice for wide-scale elimination.

questions.text:
Match the following marked structures to the correct areas of the lymph node.

       A. Germinal centre

       B. Lymphoid nodule

       C. Trabeculae

       D. Subcapsular sinus

       E. Capsule
questions.solution:
The structures marked in the above histological section of the lymph node are as follows:

1 - Capsule

2 - Subcapsular sinus

3 - Germinal centre

4 - Lymphoid nodule

5 - Trabeculae

Each lymph node consists of a connective tissue framework and of numerous lymphocytes of all types which are arranged in a stroma of reticulin fibers and cells. They form 3 major regions within each lymph node:

  1. Cortex - It contains subcapsular sinuses, lymphoid nodules, and densely packed lymphocytes. It stains darkly. Each nodule has a lightly stained germinal center surrounded by a zone of densely packed lymphocytes. 
  2. Paracortex - It lacks nodules and has fewer lymphocytes. It is, therefore, lightly stained.
  3. Medulla -  with prominent draining sinusoids adjacent to the hilum.

Given below is a histological section of a lymph node showing the cortex, paracortex, and medulla.

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent epigastric pain with burning sensation for the past 2 years. The pain usually occurs 2-3 hours after a meal and is relieved by taking food. He also says that he sometimes wakes up at night because of severe pain. The most probable cause for his symptoms is:
questions.solution:
Epigastric pain with a burning sensation that usually occurs 2-3 hours after a meal and is relieved by taking food suggestive of duodenal ulcer.

The following patterns of pain are usually seen in peptic ulcer disease:

  • Duodenal Ulcer- Pain occurs 1.5 to 3 hours after a meal and is frequently relieved by antacids or food. Pain may awaken the patient from sleep.
  • Gastric Ulcer- Pain/discomfort may be precipitated by food. Nausea and weight loss are common.
  • Perforated ulcer- The bed of the ulcer tunnels through the entire thickness of the gastric wall and opens into the peritoneum. This presents with sudden onset severe abdominal pain and leads to peritonitis. Radiography shows gas under the diaphragm.
  • Penetrating ulcer- It is a type of perforation where the ulcer tunnels into an adjacent organ like the pancreas/liver. In this case, the pain is no longer relieved by food or antacids and might radiate to the back.

Many patients with peptic ulcers, especially elderly patients, may not have these symptoms and may directly present with a complication like bleeding or perforation.

questions.text: Banana and lemon signs are seen in which fetal anomaly?
questions.solution:
Signs of neural tube defect on targeted sonography:

  • Small biparietal diameter
  • Ventriculomegaly
  • Frontal bone scalloping or the lemon sign
  • Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna known as banana sign.

questions.text: As per WHO 2017 Global Recommendation, the latest addition to the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage is:

choices.text: Late cord clamping is recommended for all births
Oxytocin 10 U IV/IM is the recommended uterotonic drug in the prevention of PPH
Intravenous oxytocin alone is the recommended uterotonic drug for the treatment of PPH
Early use of intravenous tranexamic acid is recommended in all cases of PPH

questions.solution:
The latest update in the treatment of Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH) as per WHO 2017 Global recommendations is the early use of intravenous tranexamic acid (a competitive inhibitor of plasminogen activation) is recommended in all cases of PPH.

PPH is the leading cause of maternal mortality worldwide and in India.

WHO 2012 recommendations included a conditional recommendation to use TXA for treatment of PPH when uterotonics fail to control the bleeding or the bleeding is thought to be due to trauma.

In 2017, WHO updated its 2012 PPH treatment recommendations to include the use of TXA for the treatment of PPH.

WHO 2017 Global Recommendation, the latest addition to the treatment of PPH:

  • Early use of intravenous tranexamic acid (TXA) within 3 hours of birth for women with clinically diagnosed postpartum haemorrhage (PPH).
  • TXA should be used in all cases of PPH, regardless of the cause.
  • TXA should be administered at a fixed dose of 1 g in 10 mL (100 mg/mL) IV at 1 mL per minute (i.e., administered over 10 minutes), with a second dose of 1 g IV if bleeding continues after 30 minutes.
  • TXA should be administered via an IV route only for the treatment of PPH.

WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage (2012)

  • Oxytocin (10 IU, IV/IM) is the recommended uterotonic drug for the prevention of PPH.
  • Intravenous oxytocin alone is the recommended uterotonic drug for the treatment of PPH.
  • If oxytocin is unavailable, other injectable uterotonics (ergometrine/methylergometrine or the fixed drug combination of oxytocin and ergometrine) or oral misoprostol (600 µg) is recommended.
  • Late cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births.
  • Controlled cord traction is the recommended method for removal of the placenta in caesarean section.

In 2017, the results of World Maternal Antifibrinolytic Trial showed that early use of IV TXA (within 3 hours of birth and as soon as possible after the onset of bleeding) reduces death due to bleeding in women with PPH, regardless of cause, and with no adverse maternal effects. In response to this new evidence, WHO updated its 2012 PPH treatment recommendations to include the use of TXA for the treatment of PPH. This recommendation supersedes the recommendation on TXA in the existing 2012 WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of PPH. The goals of the WHO 2017 recommendation on TXA for PPH treatment are to improve the quality of care for women with PPH and prevent maternal deaths due to PPH.

questions.text: A pregnant woman has come for her first antenatal visit at 10 weeks of gestation. How many more antenatal visits does she require to fulfill the minimum requirements as per the Maternal and Child Health program?
questions.solution:
This patient requires 3 more antenatal visits in order to fulfill the minimum requirements according to the Maternal and Child Health Program (MCH).

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to MCH is 4.

  • 1st visit – within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected.
  • 2nd visit – between 14 and 26 weeks
  • 3rd visit – between 28 and 34 weeks
  • 4th visit – between 36 weeks and term

The minimum number of antenatal visits according to the WHO is 8. Ideally, pregnant women should attend antenatal visits according to the following schedule:

  • Once a month during the first 7 months
  • Twice a month during the 8th month
  • Once a week, thereafter if everything is normal.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy rapidly develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver and kidneys are found to be enlarged. Histopathology of the liver shows deposits of glycogen in an excess amount. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given features are consistent with von Gierke's disease. It is the most common glycogen storage disease.

Enzyme deficient in this condition is glucose-6-phosphatase (common to both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis). Inheritance is autosomal recessive. 

Von Gierke disease (type I glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to the deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme in the liver, kidney, and intestinal mucosa. Patients present commonly by 3-4 months of age with hypoglycemia (leading to seizures), lactic acidosis, and hepatomegaly. Affected children often have a doll-like face with fat cheeks, relatively thin extremities, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen due to massive hepatomegaly. The kidneys are also enlarged, whereas the spleen and heart are not involved. Laboratory findings include hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

A definitive diagnosis is made using a liver biopsy. Fructose and galactose restriction in the diet is advised.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. The mother says he is irritable and drinks water hastily when given. On examination, eyes are sunken and during the skin pinch test, the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What is the treatment for the child?

choices.text: Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher center
Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day
Give zinc supplementation and oral rehydration solution only and ask mother to come back if some danger signs develop
Consider severe dehydration, start intravenous (IV) fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher center

questions.solution:
The child in this scenario has some degree of dehydration, since the child is restless and irritable, drinks water readily, has sunken eyes, and the skin goes back slowly on the skin pinch test (<2 seconds) with sunken eyes.

Treatment includes oral rehydration therapy and zinc supplementation  according to WHO Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Diseases (IMNCI) Protocol, Plan B.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator for long-term nutritional status?
questions.solution:
Height for age is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status (chronic malnutrition).

The influence of malnutrition is seen earlier in a child's weight. This means that changes in weight are more indicative of acute status, and weight-based indices are used to assess acute malnutrition. Weight for age is the most commonly used index. Changes in height occur as a result of long-term nutritional deprivation and is hence, an indicator of chronic malnutrition. A low weight for height, or wasting, also indicates acute malnutrition.

questions.text: A primigravida was taken up for emergency cesarean section in view of placental abruption, at 32 weeks of gestation. Immediately after delivery, you dry the baby, clear secretions from the mouth and nose, and provide tactile stimulation. But even after 30 seconds, you note the baby is still gasping for breath and oxygen saturation has not increased more than 92%. Which is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of respiratory distress in a preterm infant is neonatal RDS (hyaline membrane disease). The infant has presented with moderate respiratory distress without any signs of respiratory failure so early continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is the appropriate treatment.

CPAP started at birth is the choice for the management of a preterm infant at risk for respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Early nasal CPAP has shown to lower mortality and risk of bronchopulmonary dysplasia. Room air is better than oxygen for the resuscitation of preterm infants, and 100% oxygen is also harmful, causing increased oxidative stress.

The intubate-surfactant-extubate (INSURE) on CPAP technique is recommended for surfactant administration when babies showed signs of RDS and needed more than 30% inspired oxygen to maintain saturation in the normal range.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with Parkinson's disease was prescribed mirabegron to control his symptoms of urinary urgency and incontinence. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Mirabegron is a β3 agonist used for the treatment of overactive bladder (OAB). Stimulation of β3 receptors in detrusor muscle increases the bladder capacity and provides symptomatic relief in overactive bladder.

Antimuscarinic drugs are the mainstay of oral pharmacological treatment for OAB. It acts by inhibiting muscarinic receptor subtypes, M2 and M3 in the bladder. Both subtypes are expressed in multiple tissues, resulting in anticholinergic adverse events such as dry mouth, constipation, and cognitive impairment. These adverse effects are not seen with mirabegron as it acts via adrenergic receptors.

Mirabegron is a moderate inhibitor of CYP2D6. Hence, caution has to be exercised when prescribing it along with CYP2D6 substrates such as metoprolol, desipramine, digoxin.

questions.text: A child presented with fever and multiple erythematous tender plaques. On microscopic examination, the skin lesions have neutrophilic infiltration in the dermis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Neutrophilic infiltration of the dermis indicates one of the diseases under neutrophilic dermatosis. Sweet's Syndrome presents as an acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis which is characterized by non‐itchy, sometimes tender, erythematous plaques and papules.

The plaques are often oedematous and as the process develops they may become studded with pseudovesicles or pseudopustules (no fluid collection present).

The lesions in Sweet's Syndrome are most commonly distributed on the arms, upper body, head, and neck. An associated fever and peripheral leucocytosis are commonly seen and females are more frequently affected.

Histological findings include a dense dermal neutrophilic infiltrate with edema. Three subgroups are recognized:

  • Classical
  • Malignancy-associated
  • Drug-induced

Option A: Behcet's syndrome is also a neutrophilic dermatosis but presents as recurrent oral and genital aphthous ulcers with an erythematous halo.

Option B: Pyoderma gangrenosum, another neutrophilic dermatosis presents as painful ulcerative erythematous plaques or papules with undermined violaceous borders.

Option C: Kasabach-Merritt's syndrome shows hemangiomas with thrombocytopenia.

The image given below shows Sweet syndrome- pseudovesicles may occur within the inflammatory plaques.

questions.text: A patient is found to have Wernicke’s aphasia without motor involvement. Where is the infarct likely to be?

choices.text: ACA territory of the right hemisphere
ACA territory of the left hemisphere
MCA territory of the right hemisphere
MCA territory of the left hemisphere

questions.solution:
The presence of Wernicke’s aphasia without motor involvement suggests an infarct in the MCA territory of the left (dominant) hemisphere.

Wernicke’s area is located in the superior temporal gyrus in the dominant hemisphere (mostly the left side). This area is supplied by the inferior division of MCA. 

MCA divides into superior and inferior divisions in the Sylvian fissure. These branches are referred to as the M2 segments of MCA.

  • The superior division - supplies the frontal and the superior parietal cortex.
  • The inferior division - supplies the inferior parietal and temporal cortex.

An infarct in the territory of the inferior division of MCA in the dominant hemisphere causes Wernicke’s aphasia without weakness. As the frontal cortex (containing the motor area) is supplied by the superior division and is not affected, weakness is not observed.

An infarct in the inferior division of MCA of the non-dominant hemisphere (mostly the right side) causes hemineglect without weakness.

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive and tachycardic. The findings of microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear is given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Fever, fatigue, hypotension, tachycardia and the blood smear showing multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

Falciparum malaria, or malignant tertian malaria, is the most serious malaria. Plasmodium falciparum infects both young and mature erythrocytes, resulting in a large population of erythrocytes affected. Affected erythrocytes display cytoadherence, form rosettes and cause capillary plugging in vital organs like the brain, kidney, lungs etc. Diagnosis is by demonstration of P. falciparum in peripheral blood smear. The peripheral smear findings of falciparum malaria include:

  • Multiple ring forms: Multiple delicate rings are visible within the erythrocytes
  • Double chromatin: Binucleate ring forms resembling stereo headphones
  • Accole form or form applique: Ring forms are attached to the margins of red cells
  • Maurer's dots or clefts: Coarse brick red dots within erythrocytes
  • Banana shaped gametocytes within erythrocytes
  • Absent schizont

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding TGF-β?

choices.text: It  increases the synthesis of collagen
It increases the degradation of the extracellular matrix
It is involved in the development of fibrosis in solid organs

questions.solution:
TGF-β (transforming growth factor-β) decreases the degradation of the extracellular matrix by inhibiting metalloproteinases.

It is produced by most cells in granulation tissue, including alternatively activated macrophages.

The functions of TGF-β include:

  • Stimulates fibroblast migration and proliferation
  • Increases synthesis of collagen and fibronectin (connective tissue proteins)
  • Decreased degradation of ECM by inhibiting metalloproteinases
  • Involved in scar formation after injury
  • Development of fibrosis in lung, liver, and kidneys following chronic inflammation
  • Anti-inflammatory action by inhibiting lymphocyte proliferation and activity

questions.text: A couple visits the psychiatrist’s office with the husband complaining that his wife is cheating on him, but he did not have any evidence. In a private conversation with his wife, she revealed that the husband had a reputation of having multiple affairs with his colleagues in the past. In this scenario, which defense mechanism is the husband using?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the husband is using projection as a defense mechanism. Projection is when you attribute your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a site for heme synthesis?
questions.solution:
Mature erythrocyte is not a site for heme biosynthesis.

Approximately 85% of heme synthesis occurs in erythroid precursor cells in the bone marrow and the majority of the remainder in hepatocytes. Heme biosynthesis occurs both in mitochondria and cytoplasm. It is initiated by the condensation of succinyl–CoA and glycine in a reaction catalyzed by mitochondrial ALA synthase. This initial reaction, and the last three steps in the formation of heme occur in mitochondria, whereas the intermediate steps of the biosynthetic pathway occur in the cytosol.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy was accidentally shot in the eye by his brother while playing with a pellet gun. Examination reveals intraocular contents presenting at the wound. He is scheduled for emergency repair of the ruptured globe. What is the ideal anaesthetic technique to be used?
questions.solution:
General anaesthesia is the ideal anaesthetic technique to be used in a person who has to undergo surgery for a penetrating eye injury.

Regional anaesthesia is relatively contraindicated in patients with penetrating eye injuries because injecting local anaesthetic behind the globe increases intraocular pressure and may lead to the expulsion of intraocular contents.

Therefore these patients require general anaesthesia—despite the increased risk of aspiration pneumonia when it is administered.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the OPD with fever, lower abdominal pain and purulent vaginal discharge. On examination, her vitals are stable and per vaginal examination reveals lower abdominal and cervical motion tenderness. What is the best treatment option for her?

choices.text: Single IM injection of ceftriaxone 250 mg with oral doxycycline and metronidazole for 14 days
Single IM injection of ceftriaxone 250 mg  with oral metronidazole 400 mg for 7 days
Oral doxycycline 100 mg BD with oral metronidazole  400 mg for 7 days
Oral ofloxacin 200 mg BD with oral metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever and lower abdominal pain associated with lower abdominal and cervical motion tenderness is suggestive of PID. The best treatment option for this patient is outpatient treatment with a single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg + oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/- metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days.

Outpatient treatment of PID (according to the current RCOG guidelines):

  • A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg + oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/- metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days
  • A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by azithromycin 1 gm per week x 2 weeks.

Treatment of PID in hospitalized patients:

  • Cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV  for 48 hours is given followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg +/- metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days
  • Cefoxitin 2 g IV 6hourly + doxycycline 100 mg IV followed by oral route.
  • Azithromycin 500 mg IV 6 hourly for 2 days, then orally for Chlamydia.

questions.text: A patient being evaluated for primary aldosteronism underwent selective adrenal venous sampling. A comparison of the samples obtained from both the adrenal veins showed a significant difference in the aldosterone-cortisol ratio. What is the preferred line of treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Medical treatment with spironolactone and supplemental antihypertensives

questions.solution:
During selective adrenal vein sampling, a significant difference in the aldosterone-cortisol ratio on one side indicates unilateral hyperaldosteronism. In this case, unilateral laparoscopic adrenalectomy is the treatment of choice.

Primary hyperaldosteronism (PHA) is characterized by hypersecretion of aldosterone with suppressed plasma renin levels (due to the negative feedback). The most frequent cause of PHA is unilateral adenoma.

CT or MRI is used to detect the tumour. In a patient with bilateral micronodular hyperplasia, there could be a unilateral non-functioning tumour. Selective adrenal vein sampling can be done to differentiate between unilateral and bilateral disease.

Conservative management with 3-6 months of MRI surveillance is done in non-functional adrenal tumours of < 4cm.

Medical management is done in patients with bilateral disease, the commonly implemented therapeutic approach is treatment with spironolactone and antihypertensive medication.

Surgical management is done in unilateral and asymmetrical bilateral disease by unilateral laparoscopic adrenalectomy. A subtotal resection can be considered in the case of a typical single Conn’s adenoma. However, it is not superior to unilateral adrenalectomy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has recently started work in the stone cutting industry. The company provides him with a respirator mask but they do not use dust control measures. If he works in similar conditions for 20 more years, which of the following will you most likely see in his HRCT scan image?

choices.text: Small round opacities in upper lobes
Thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma

questions.solution:
In this scenario, the man works in the stone cutting industry, indicating exposure to silica. He is expected to have less intense, long term exposure owing to a few but substandard measures to control exposure to silica. Such individuals are more likely to develop simple silicosis. These patients are asymptomatic, and HRCT shows small round opacities in the upper lobes.

This can progress to complicated silicosis. Here, the nodules coalesce and form masses leading to impairment of lung function. They present with chronic cough and progressive dyspnoea on exertion. This may progress further to cause progressive massive fibrosis. 

PFT shows a mixed obstructive and restrictive pattern. Calcification of hilar lymph nodes is seen in a few cases, called eggshell calcification. This is depicted in the image below.

Option A: A crazy pavement pattern is seen with acute silicosis.

Option C: Thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma are seen in pulmonary lymphangiomyomatosis (LAM).

Option D: Pleural plaques are seen in patients suffering from asbestosis.

questions.text: Succinate-Q reductase belongs to which complex of the ETC?
questions.solution:
Succinate Q reductase belongs to complex II of ETC.

Components include FAD and Fe-S. It receives electrons from succinate and donates it to a mobile carrier, coenzyme Q, thereby, reducing it and then to complex III.

There is a catalyzed oxidation of succinate to fumarate.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child is brought with enlargement of the right testis. USG shows a 3cm solid mass within the body of the testis. Serum AFP is 230 ng/ml. Orchidectomy specimen revealed a nonencapsulated tumour having a homogeneous, yellow-white, mucinous appearance. The microscopy image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the above clinical scenario is the yolk sac tumor of the testis (Endodermal sinus tumour). 

The given microscopic image shows a lacelike reticular network of cuboidal tumour cells and Schiller duval bodies.

Yolk sac tumor is the most common testicular tumor in infants and children up to 3 years of age. In this age group, it has a very good prognosis.

 

Eosinophilic, hyaline-like globules may be present within and outside the cytoplasm in which α-fetoprotein (AFP) and α1-antitrypsin can be demonstrated by immunocytochemical staining.

questions.text: Protein buffers are rich in which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
Protein buffers are rich in histidine. 

Proteins play a significant role as intracellular buffers in the body. The buffer effect of proteins is contributed by the dissociable side groups. For most proteins, including hemoglobin, the most important buffer group is the imidazole ring of histidine residues.

The other major buffer group is the α-amino terminals found in proteins. All the other dissociable groups found in proteins have a pKa that is either too low or too high and thus contributes very little to buffering.

questions.text: A female from Himachal Pradesh presented with H/O thorn prick, a year back has a verrucous lesion in the skin with the following microscopic findings. Identify the agent?

questions.solution:
The structure marked A is the allantois.
