questions.text: Which of the following are transmitted biologically by invertebrate vectors?
questions.solution:
Metazoonoses are a type of zoonoses where the infective agents are transmitted by invertebrate vectors. They multiply and develop within the invertebrates (extrinsic incubation period) before transmission to a vertebrate host.

A zoonosis is any disease or infection that is naturally transmissible from vertebrate animals to humans. They can be classified based on their reservoir hosts into:

  • Anthropozoonoses - transmitted from lower vertebrates to man
  • Zooanthroponoses - transmitted from man to lower vertebrates 
  • Amphixenoses - may be transmitted in either direction

They can also be classified based on the life cycle of the infecting agent:

Category

Mode

Example

Direct zoonoses

Direct contact, fomites, mechanical vector

No developmental or propagative changes during transmission

Rabies, brucellosis, trichinosis

Cyclo-zoonoses

Require > 1 vertebrate host to complete the developmental cycle

Human taeniasis, Echinococcosis, Pentastomid infections

Meta-zoonoses

Transmitted by invertebrate vectors 

Infective agent develops and multiplies within the invertebrate (extrinsic incubation period) after which it is transmitted to another vertebrate host

Arboviral infections, plague and schistosomiasis

Sapro-zoonoses

Has both a vertebrate host and a non-animal (food, soil, plants) developmental site or reservoir

Various forms of larva migrans and mycoses

questions.text: A middle-aged woman diagnosed with depression presented to your OPD for a follow-up. You notice a characteristic sign marked by an arrow in the image. Identify this sign.
questions.solution:
In the given image, the arrow indicates Veraguth's sign or Veraguth's fold, a diagonal palpebral fold running from the lateral corners of the eyes, medially upward to the medial end of the eyebrows. It is a physical sign of depression.

Another physical sign of depression is the Omega sign. In this, there is vertical wrinkling between the eyebrows joined at the top by a horizontal crease.

questions.text: On autopsy of a person with suspected poisoning, a characteristic finding of softening of basal ganglia is found. Which of the following is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Softening of the basal ganglia is a characteristic postmortem finding in case of carbon monoxide poisoning.

Softening of basal ganglia is seen in:

  • Carbon monoxide poisoning
  • Cyanide poisoning

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presented with umbilical discharge. Abdomen examination was normal except for the below finding. The next step of management is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical image is that of a congenital umbilical anomaly such as patent urachus, urachal cyst, and vitelline cyst (resulting from the persistence of omphalomesenteric duct). The next best step is the USG abdomen to diagnose if the anomaly is cystic, fibrous or fistula and it's connections. 

Omphalomesenteric duct abnormalities: Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the connection between the yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which eventually gets obliterated. The persistence of the vitellointestinal duct leads to various abnormalities depending on which part of the duct remains patent.

  • Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel’s diverticula.
  • Persistence of the distal end near the umbilicus leads to the umbilical polyp or sinus.
  • Persistence of the distal end with mucus retention leads to the cyst, which may be associated with the intestine or the umbilicus by a fibrous band.
  • A fully patent vitellointestinal duct can lead to an enterocutaneous fistula.

Patent urachus occurs due to the failure of urachus to obliterate, resulting in a connection between the bladder and the umbilicus.

Urachal cyst occurs when the urachus fails to obliterate but there is no connection between the bladder and the umbilicus.

The given image below shows a urachal cyst (UC) attached to Meckel’s diverticulum (MD) on one side and urinary bladder (UB) on the other side with a patent tract- urachus (U).

questions.text: A 16-year-old gymnast was brought to the emergency department after suffering severe trauma during the performance. She presented with painful hip instability. MRI revealed ligament tear which is caused by hyperextension of the hip joint. Which of the following​ ligaments is likely to be torn?
questions.solution:
The iliofemoral ligament resists the hyperextension of hip joint and hence, is likely to be injured.

Iliofemoral ligament or ligament of Bigelow is the strongest ligament of the hip joint. It is an inverted-Y-shaped ligament. The apex is attached between the anterior inferior iliac spine and acetabular margin. The base is attached to the intertrochanteric line. This ligament prevents the hyperextension of the hip joint.

The image given below shows the iliofemoral ligament.

questions.text: Which of the following organizations regulates the clinical trials and approval of investigational new drugs in India?
questions.solution:
Central Drug Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO) regulates the clinical trials and approval of investigational new drugs in India. 

The CDSCO is also responsible for laying down the standards for drugs, controlling the quality of imported drugs in the country and coordinating the activities of State Drug Control Organizations. The proposal for initiating trials, review of clinical trial results, and recommendations for marketing authorization is done through a committee called the Investigational New Drug (IND) Committee formed by CDSCO. 

The Drugs Controller General of India (DCGI) is the head of the CDSCO, under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in India. 

Preclinical trials are performed on animals, and they are regulated by guidelines prescribed by the Committee for the Purpose of the Control and Supervision of Experiments on Animals (CPCSEA) in India.

questions.text: A mother brings her 2-month-old blue baby to your pediatric clinic for the first time. Neonatal records were not available but the mother says that the X-ray of the baby looked like that of a shoe. Which of the following wouldn't you expect in this baby?

choices.text: Large "a" waves in jugular venous pulse

questions.solution:
The given history of the shoe (boot) shaped heart in cyanotic baby is suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot and cardiomegaly is not a part of TOF presentation. 

In the tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), we see concentric right ventricular hypertrophy without cardiac enlargement. It is because of pulmonary stenosis (PS) and the ventricular septal defect (VSD). Any build-up of pressure in the right ventricle due to PS is released through VSD to the left ventricle.

Option A: P2 is of low intensity and soft because the right ventricular outflow obstruction results in reduced pulmonary artery pressure.

Option B: The aortic root usually appears large because it overrides (straddling) the VSD, allowing deoxygenated blood shunted from the right ventricle mixed with blood from the left ventricle to exit the heart.

Option D: The large 'a' wave in the jugular pulse is a reflection of the forceful contraction of the right atrium at the end of diastole as there is reduced distensibility of the hypertrophic right ventricle.

questions.text: In a case of acute exacerbation of asthma, salbutamol was given, however, no improvement was noticed. Intravenous corticosteroids and aminophylline were given and the condition improved. What is the probable mechanism by which the corticosteroids would have improved the condition?

choices.text: Corticosteroids increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol
Corticosteroids cause direct bronchodilatation when used with xanthines
Corticosteroids indirectly increase the effect of xanthines on adenosine receptor

questions.solution:
Corticosteroids improved the condition by increasing the airway responsiveness to salbutamol.

Mechanism of action of corticosteroids in an acute asthma attack:

  • Increases responsiveness to β-2 agonists
  • Decreases mucous secretion
  • Decreases inflammatory cell response.

Steroids increase the transcription of β-2 receptor genes and hence increases responsiveness to β-2 agonists.

β-2 agonists increase the effect of steroids by enhancing the action of glucocorticoid receptors.

Theophylline increases the effects of steroids by activating the enzyme histone deacetylase which is the target for steroids as well.

Note: As per recent GINA 2021 guidelines, aminophyllines are no longer preferred in the management of acute severe asthma due to their low efficacy and poor safety profile.

questions.text: A child presents with perioral rash and pigmentation of palmar area. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
Dermatitis of extremities and around orifices is typical of zinc deficiency.

Other features of zinc deficiency include:

  1. Decreased growth
  2. Impaired immunity
  3. Poor wound healing
  4. Hypogonadism
  5. Diarrhea

Option B: Copper deficiency leads to neurological manifestations like peripheral neuropathy, and there is depigmentation of hair and skin

Option C: Manganese deficiency presents with hypercholesterolemia and weight loss

Option D: Selenium deficiency presents as cardiomyopathy (Keshan's disease)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a solitary, non-tender, firm nodule on the left side of her neck. Thyroid function tests were within normal limits. A fine-needle biopsy revealed malignant cells. The tumor was excised and examined under light microscopy as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of empty appearing nuclei, also called Orphan Annie eye nuclei as seen in the above image is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma include:

  • Branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk
  • Covering epithelium is simple or stratified cuboidal
  • Orphan Annie eye nuclei - 
    • Empty-appearing nuclei due to dispersed chromatin
    • They are diagnostic, regardless of papillary architecture
  • Psammoma bodies - concentric calcified structures
  • Foci of lymphatic invasion 

Note: Orphan Annie refers to a comic book character with empty appearing eyes, as shown below.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: A patient has presented to the OPD with raised erythematous plaques on his arms and torso covered in silvery scales. You decide to prescribe a monoclonal antibody targeting interleukin-23 for treatment. Identify this drug.
questions.solution:
The scenario described in the question points towards a diagnosis of chronic plaque psoriasis. Tildrakizumab is a monoclonal antibody directed against IL-23 used in the treatment of this condition.

IL-23 is a naturally occurring cytokine that is involved in inflammatory and immune responses. Tildrakizumab prevents the interaction of IL-23 with its receptors. It is indicated in moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis.

Secukinumab, ixekizumab, brodalumab are other monoclonal antibodies directed against IL-17A and indicated in moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis.

Note: Ustekinumab is a monoclonal antibody against both IL-12 and IL-23. It is used for the treatment of Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, plaque psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A pediatrician carried out a study to assess the difference in growth velocities in boys and girls. The average height of a group of 20 boys aged 10 years was 140 ± 13 cm and for 20 girls of the same age was 135 ± 7 cm. To test the statistical significance of the difference in height, which test would she use?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, two independent groups are being compared with quantitative variables. Thus, a student t test or unpaired t-test is used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: ECG of a patient who was brought to the casualty due to severe chest pain followed by syncope is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ECG is suggestive of atrial flutter.

The given ECG shows narrow QRS complexes, hence it is supraventricular tachycardia. The RR intervals are regular and the normal P waves are replaced by sawtooth-shaped waves, known as flutter waves.

In atrial flutter, the ventricular rate is determined by the AV conduction ratio. The commonest AV ratio is 2:1. In the above ECG, the rhythm is atrial flutter 4:1 block with an atrial rate of about 270 and a ventricular rate of 68/min.

The image below shows sawtooth shaped waves in atrial flutter.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the classification of malaria endemic states under the National Strategic Plan for Malaria?

choices.text: The states classified under Category 0  are in the elimination phase
The states with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1 are in the elimination phase
The states with districts reporting API in between 1-2 per 1000 population are in the elimination phase
The states classified under category 2 are in the phase of intensified control

questions.solution:
The National Strategic Plan for Malaria classifies the states under Category 1 of the NVBDCP to be in the elimination phase. 

Category 1 states are all states/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1.

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016-2030)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to <1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Classification of states/UTs according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Criteria  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥1.   Same as category 2

 

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly, all the districts are classified into the following four categories:

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in the last 3 years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  Districts with API <1 per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between 1-2 per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts with API >2 per 1000 population.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goal of NSP strategy is the phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as the goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1-2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at <1 by 2022.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient comes to the OPD with a history significant for a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as done in the image given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing 3 episodes of mania and 2 episodes of depression within 1 year, points towards a diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder. 

It is diagnosed when the patient has a combination of 4 or more alternating episodes of depression and mania/hypomania within one year. There must be less than 2 weeks of normalcy between the episodes or an immediate shift between the symptoms with no intervening normal mood.

Risk factors:

  • Female patients
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alcoholism or substance abuse
  • Antidepressants (if used without mood stabilizers)
  • Cyclothymia
  • Bipolar II disorder

Note: If the phases of mania and depression alternate very rapidly in a matter of hours or days then the condition is known as ultra-rapid cycling disorder.

World Bipolar Day (WBD) is celebrated each year on March 30th to bring world awareness about bipolar disorders and to eliminate the social stigma. The theme for the year 2023 is "BipolarTogether"

questions.text: A G3A3 patient was admitted to the hospital with catastrophic APLS following a spontaneous abortion. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is a rapidly progressive thromboembolic disorder
At least 2 organ systems should be involved to make a diagnosis
Infections can act as a trigger
IVIG can be used for treatment

questions.solution:
Catastrophic antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (CAPS) is a complication of APLA syndrome, in which ≥3 organ systems are involved. It is also known as Asherson syndrome.

It is seen in both primary and secondary APLA syndrome. Triggering factors include infections, trauma, and obstetric causes. IVIG can be used in CAPS when the first-line therapies with aspirin and heparin have failed.

Note: Asherman syndrome is an acquired condition characterised by formation of intrauterine adhesions or synechiae.

questions.text: What is Glaukomflecken?
questions.solution:
Glaukomflecken is anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity and a component of Vogt's triad seen in patients after an acute angle closure glaucoma attack. 

The Vogt's triad comprises of:

  • Glaukomflecken
  • Patches of iris atrophy
  • Slightly dilated nonreactive pupil

questions.text: The mechanism of action of MgSo4 includes all, except:

choices.text: It reduces motor endplate sensitivity to Ach

questions.solution:
MgSO4 blocks calcium influx, not sodium.

Mechanism of action of MgSO4:

  • It is a membrane stabilizer and acts as a neuroprotector by reducing motor endplate sensitivity to Ach.
  • It blocks neuronal calcium influx.
  • It reduces the presynaptic release of the neurotransmitter glutamate.

questions.text: You suspect a lymphoid neoplasm in a patient who is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis. On workup, she has splenomegaly and her blood count showed neutropenia and lymphocytosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A triad of rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia is known as Felty's syndrome. Some patients with Felty's syndrome have large granular lymphocytic leukemia as an underlying cause.

Large granular lymphocytic leukemia is a T-cell (CD3+) and NK-cell (CD56+) variant leukemia. They are associated with mutations in the transcription factor, STAT3.

Patients usually presents with mild to moderate lymphocytosis and splenomegaly. Neutropenia and anemia are also present. Lymphadenopathy and hepatomegaly are usually absent. 

There is an increased incidence of rheumatological disorders associated with this condition.

The peripheral smear picture shows large lymphocytes with abundant blue cytoplasm and few azurophilic granules.

questions.text: A 1-year old boy presented with loss of motor skills, increased startle response to noise and seizures. On fundoscopy, the following image was seen. Further evaluation reveals the diagnosis of a lysosomal storage disorder.  Which of the following enzymes is most likely defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
An infant with loss of motor skills, increased startle response to noise and seizures (neurological involvement) and a cherry-red spot in the macula suggests Tay-Sachs disease. This disease is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A.

Tay-Sachs disease is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting in the deficiency of hexosaminidase A. As a result, GM2 gangliosides are not degraded and they accumulate within lysosomes.  Affected children present with loss of motor skills, increased startle response, seizures, hyperacusis, macrocephaly, neurodegeneration, blindness and muscular weakness. Cherry-red spots are seen in the macula of eye.

Note: The clinical features of Sandhoff's disease, due to deficiency of hexosaminidase A and B, are similar to Tay-Sachs. Affected children additionally have hepatosplenomegaly and cardiac involvement.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presented to the casualty with vomiting and severe colicky pain in the abdomen for the past 48 hours. She had undergone a weight reduction surgery six months ago and had achieved around 30% weight loss. Her plain X-ray abdomen is given below. Which of the following bariatric procedures was most likely done in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and radiograph (dilated bowel segments with valvulae conniventes in the left upper quadrant) are suggestive of small bowel obstruction. Bariatric surgery, specifically, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery is associated with the creation of mesenteric defects. The small bowel can herniate through these defects (internal hernia) and get strangulated, resulting in bowel obstruction. 

In addition, as the person loses weight (due to the bariatric procedure), the protective, space-occupying effect of the mesenteric fat is lost and hernia spaces open up, further increasing the risk of internal hernia. The laparoscopic procedure has a higher risk compared to open surgery since fewer adhesions form to tether small-bowel loops and prevent them from herniating. 

Adequate closure of the mesenteric defects by the surgeon at the time of operation significantly reduces the risk of internal hernia.

Other complications specific to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass:

  • Nutritional deficiencies: iron (most common), folate, Vitamin A, D, K and B12      
  • Anastomosis site leak      
  • Bleeding from the site of gastrojejunostomy   
  • Dumping syndrome
  • Marginal ulcers
  • Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism

Option A: Sleeve gastrectomy is often complicated by staple line leak.

Option B: Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding is associated with band slippage and erosion.

Option D: Endoluminal stapling is also used to create a gastric sleeve. It is associated with postoperative nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and transient dysphagia.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with chronic alcoholism presented with severe right-sided upper abdominal pain. On examination, her SOFA score was 3. An abdominal CT was done which is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the CT showing gas within the wall of the gallbladder is suggestive of emphysematous cholecystitis.

Emphysematous cholecystitis is a rare form of acute cholecystitis where gallbladder wall necrosis causes gas formation intramurally or intraluminally. 

This condition occurs most frequently in elderly males or patients with diabetes. Secondary infection of the gallbladder wall with gas-forming organisms such as Clostridium welchii/ C. perfringens leads to emphysematous cholecystitis, and aerobes such as Escherichia coli may also be isolated. Patients present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever. Crepitus is present on physical examination.

On imaging, the air is seen in the gallbladder wall and/or biliary ducts, in the absence of abnormal communication with the gastrointestinal tract is seen.

Emphysematous cholecystitis has a high mortality rate due to the development of gangrene, perforation, and other complications. Hence, emergency cholecystectomy is indicated for the management of these patients. 

 

The given image shows a postoperative specimen of an emphysematous gallbladder along with an X-ray showing air in the gallbladder wall.

questions.text: A 23 year old patient presents with lesions in the groin as shown in the image below. Which of the following cannot be a cause of these lesions?
questions.solution:
The image shows a well-circumscribed, annular plaque in the groin region which is characteristic of tinea cruris. Tinea cruris is a dermatophytosis. Trichophyton, Microsporum and Epidermophyton are dermatophytes whereas Aspergillus is not.

Dermatophytes include 3 genera: 

  1. Trichophyton species infect skin, hair, and nails and include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, and T. violaceum.
  2. Microsporum contains M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. These infect only hair and skin (not nails).
  3. Floccosum is the only species in the genus Epidermophyton, It infects only skin and nails (not hair).

Aspergillus spp. produce large necrotic lesions like ecthyma gangrenosum, and sometimes small papules and cold abscesses.

questions.text: When the membrane potential decreases from +35 mV to -40 mV, the voltage-gated sodium channels are most likely to be in which state?
questions.solution:
When the membrane potential is decreasing towards the resting potential (becomes more negative), the Na+ channels are most likely to be in their inactivated state (C in the given image).

Voltage-Gated Sodium Channels have two gates— an activation gate near the outside of the channel and an inactivation gate near the inside.

Resting-State (Image A): The membrane potential is initially -70 mv and the activation gate is closed at this stage. This prevents any entry of sodium ions to the interior of the fiber through these sodium channels.

  • Activated State (Image B): When the membrane potential rises from -70 millivolts toward zero, it causes a sudden conformational change in the activation gate, flipping it to the open position. During this activated state, sodium ions can move inward through the channel. 
  • Inactivated State (Image C): The rise in membrane potential toward zero also produces a conformational change that flips the inactivation gate to the closed state. But this is a slower process compared to the opening of the activation gate. Therefore, the inactivation gate closes a few 10,000ths of a second after the sodium channel has opened and sodium ions can no longer move inside. Following this, the membrane potential begins to return toward the resting membrane state, which is the repolarization process.

The inactivation gate will not reopen until the membrane potential returns to or near the original resting membrane potential level. Therefore, the sodium channels can only open after the nerve fiber is repolarized.

questions.text: A 40-year old man who is suffering from open-angle glaucoma reads about netarsudil being approved as a novel agent for his condition. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution: Netarsudil is a rho kinase inhibitor that acts by relaxing the trabecular meshwork. This increases the outflow of aqueous humor and reduces intraocular pressure.

questions.text: After the administration of a drug for an acute attack of migraine, a patient developed nausea and vomiting. She also developed tingling and numbness at the tips of her fingers that eventually turned blue. Which of the following is the most likely drug implicated?

Nausea and vomiting, as well as tingling and numbness (paresthesia), are common adverse effects of dihydroergotamine.

  • Uncontrolled hypertension
  • Fever and/or sepsis
  • Pregnancy
  • Within 24 hours of using triptans

questions.text: A patient's ECG shows a short PR interval and delta wave. Additional findings include atrial fibrillation and rapid ventricular rate. He is hemodynamically stable. All of the following drugs can be used in the management except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a patient with WPW syndrome with atrial fibrillation.

Rate-slowing drugs such as non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (eg, verapamil, diltiazem), beta-blockers, and digoxin are contraindicated in these patients. They increase the refractoriness of the AV node with minimal or no effect on the accessory pathway. This can lead to faster ventricular rates, increasing the risk of ventricular fibrillation.

 The ECG below shows a short PR interval (<120 ms) and delta waves in WPW syndrome. 

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: A 19-year-old lady delivered a neonate with the following defect. Which of the following statements about the defect is false?

choices.text: The defect is generally located to the right of the umbilical cord
Herniation of liver is commonly associated with this condition
The incidence of this defect is more in preterm babies
Serial reduction of eviscerated intestines maybe done for management

questions.solution:
The above image shows gastroschisis. Herniation of the liver is more commonly seen with omphalocele than gastroschisis.

Gastroschisis represents a congenital anomaly characterized by a defect in the anterior abdominal wall. The abdominal contents protrude through this defect. It is the most common anomaly seen in babies born to mothers under 20 years of age. Unlike omphalocele, there is no overlying sac and the size of the defect is usually <4 cm.

An orogastric tube is placed to decompress the stomach. For primary closure, bowel loops are reduced, fascia and skin are approximated.

If the viscera cannot be reduced into the abdomen, a silo is placed at the bedside as shown in the image. The eviscerated intestines are reduced serially during 5 to 7 days, followed by operative fascial closure.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of a vitreous hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for vitreous hemorrhage is ultrasonography (USG) B-scan. Mild hemorrhage causes sudden onset floaters and diffuse blurring of vision, but may not affect visual acuity, whilst a dense bleed may result in sudden painless loss of vision. 

B-mode ultrasonography(B-scan) in unclotted vitreous hemorrhage generally shows a uniform appearance, and once cellular aggregates develop, small particulate echoes become visible.

Causes of vitreous hemorrhage:

  • Proliferative retinopathy
    • Diabetic
    • Retinal vein occlusion
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Eales disease
    • Vasculitis
  • Miscellaneous retinal disorders
    • Macroaneurysm
    • Telangiectasia
    • Capillary hemangioma
  • Trauma
  • Systemic
    • Bleeding disorders
    • Terson syndrome- refers to the combination of intraocular and subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to aneurysmal rupture, most commonly arising from the anterior communicating artery.

Treatment is dictated by severity and cause, but an increasingly low threshold is being adopted for early vitrectomy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient came with complaints of episodes of shortness of breath and coughing at night which awakens him from sleep. On examination, distended neck veins were observed and S3 was heard on auscultation. Which of the following biomarkers can be used for the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of heart failure. The brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) can be used to confirm this.

Natriuretic peptides are protein molecules that are secreted by the ventricular myocytes in response to volume or pressure overload. Ventricular musculature releases pre-proBNP which is cleaved into active BNP and inert NT-proBNP.

BNP causes natriuresis, vasodilatation, and diuresis that leads to improved myocardial relaxation.  These peptides also counteract the actions of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Measurement of both BNP and inert NT-proBNP levels can be used in the diagnosis of heart failure and to determine the prognosis.

questions.text: A patient with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy develops nephrotic-range proteinuria. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to a secondary cause (reflux nephropathy). Secondary nephrotic syndrome in adults is most likely due to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).

FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells and effacement of foot processes. Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis are seen due to the entrapment of plasma proteins and increased extracellular matrix deposition.

FSGS is classified as follows:

  • Primary
    • Idiopathic FSGS
  • Secondary
    • HIV associated
    • Heroin addiction
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Obesity
    • Hypertensive nephropathy
    • Renal conditions
      • Focal glomerulonephritis (e.g. IgA nephropathy)
      • Renal ablation
      • Unilateral renal agenesis or renal dysplasia
      • Reflux nephropathy
  • Inherited
    • Mutated proteins of the slit diaphragm - podocin, alpha-actinin 4, TRPC6

Electron microscopy of FSGS shows: 

  • Diffuse effacement of the podocyte foot processes
  • Focal detachment and degeneration of the epithelial cells
  • Absence of electron-dense deposits

questions.text: While assessing the health needs of a community, an epidemiologist is tasked with estimating the burden of cholera in the area. Which of the following is the simplest measure he can use?
questions.solution:
The proportional mortality rate is the simplest measure of estimating the burden of disease in the community. It signifies the proportion of all deaths that can be attributed to the disease.

It is calculated as follows:

Proportional mortality rate of a disease = (No. of deaths due to that disease in the year/ Total no. of deaths in the year) *100.

Option A: Case fatality rate measures the risk of persons dying from a certain disease within a given time period. It measures the killing power of a disease. It is used to link mortality to morbidity.

Option B: Incidence measures the rate at which new cases are occurring in a population. It is not influenced by the duration of the disease. The use of incidence is generally restricted to acute diseases.

Option C: Crude death rate is considered a fair indicator of the comparative health of the people. It is the rate of total deaths in a year compared to the mid-year population.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy with Ewing's sarcoma is on chemotherapy. Which of the following is an indicator of poor prognosis?

Indicators of poor prognosis in patients with Ewing's sarcoma:

  • Presence of distant metastasis - worst prognostic factor
  • Size and location of the primary lesion
  • Presence of fever, anaemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Raised ESR
  • Male child and age 12–15 years

Histologic grade is of no prognostic significance because all Ewing's sarcomas are considered high grade.

Note: High levels of beta 2 microglobulin is an indicator of poor prognosis in multiple myeloma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cell adhesion molecule (CAM)?
questions.solution:
Spectrin is a cytoskeletal protein but not a cell adhesion molecule.

Cells are attached to each other or to the basal lamina by cell adhesion molecules (CAMs). Some important classes of CAMs are: 

  • Integrins: heterodimers that bind to various receptors
  • IgG superfamily of immunoglobulins
  • Cadherins: Ca2+-dependent molecules that mediate cell-to-cell adhesion by homophilic reactions
  • Selectins which have lectin-like domains that bind carbohydrates

Clinical significance

  • Cancer cells have abnormal CAMs and hence cause decreased cell adhesion and allow individual cancer cells to detach from the parent cancer.
  • The decrease in the amount of E-cadherin maybe the reason for early metastasis of numerous tumors.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with complaints of intolerance to loud sounds and mild giddiness associated with ringing in the ear. What is the probable cause of intolerance to loud sounds in this patient?
questions.solution:
Intolerance to loud sounds in this patient is due to the recruitment phenomenon (sound is amplified to be heard better). It is a feature of all cochlear pathologies.

The characteristic presentation of a middle-aged man with vertigo, tinnitus, and intolerance to loud sounds points to a diagnosis of Ménière’s disease. It is a cochlear pathology, hence shows the recruitment phenomenon.

The rollover phenomenon is a feature of retro-cochlear pathologies like an acoustic neuroma.

Diplacusis is the perception of a single auditory stimulus as sounds of a different pitch in two ears.

Tullio phenomenon is a condition where loud sounds precipitate a vertiginous attack.

questions.text: Identify the organism from the given image.
questions.solution:
The organism shown in the image is Nocardia asteroides.

Nocardia species are weakly acid-fast filamentous organisms with hyphae-like branching on microscopy. They are aerobic, gram-positive, catalase-positive, and urease-positive. They are weakly acid-fast because they stain with carbolfuchsin and retain when decolourized with 1–4% sulfuric acid instead of the stronger acid-alcohol decolorant.

Infection follows traumatic inoculation of the organism into the subcutaneous tissue from soil or vegetable sources. They can present with a characteristic powdery substance that appears as gritty or necrotic material on the skin or within soft tissues. Accompanying this are multiple discharging sinuses, which are abnormal openings that form as the body attempts to expel infected material. These sinuses can drain purulent, often foul-smelling discharge typically associated with localised abscesses, and the discharge may be viscous, sometimes containing necrotic tissue.

Other options:

Options A and B: Mycobacteria species are acid-fast but not have branching filaments.

Option C: Actinomyces species are not acid-fast. They are Gram-positive arranged in a sun-ray appearance.

questions.text: A microbiologist is about to run a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay on the serum of a patient suspected to have Q fever. He wishes to quantify the PCR by monitoring the amplification process while the PCR is ongoing. Which of the following types of PCR should he perform?
questions.solution:
Real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) can be used to quantify the PCR by monitoring the amplification process while the PCR is ongoing. 

Polymerase chain reaction is a rapid method used to amplify specific DNA sequences. It consists of several cycles of sequential DNA replication. Types of PCR include:

  • Reverse transcriptase PCR- The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complementary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR.
  • Real-time PCR- This helps quantify the PCR and gives an estimate of the pathogen DNA load in the specimen. It uses fluorescent dyes or specific DNA probes. It is also known as qPCR (Quantitative PCR)
  • Multiplex PCR- Primers to more than one pathogen are used simultaneously and hence multiple products are obtained. 
  • Nested PCR- It involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification and the amplicon obtained is then used as a target sequence for second amplification. This ensures specificity.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man was brought to the emergency with a profusely bleeding scalp laceration following a road traffic accident. What is the nature and layer of origin of the bleed?
questions.solution:
Scalp bleeding is predominantly arterial, from the dense connective tissue of the scalp. 

Profuse bleeding from scalp injuries occurs due to: 

  1. Low venous pressure in the erect posture
  2. The dense connective tissue holds the arteries open and does not allow them to retract causing profuse bleeding.

The scalp has an extremely rich blood supply from the external carotid arteries. Profuse bleeding from a scalp laceration is usually fatal unless it's quickly controlled by sutures.

questions.text: A patient with HIV presented complaining of cough and progressively worsening breathing difficulty. Chest X-ray showed bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The Gomori methamine silver-stained smear of his bronchoalveolar lavage is given below. What is the most probable causative organism and the typical CD4+ count this infection occurs at?
questions.solution:
Cough, progressive dyspnea, bilateral interstitial infiltrates and the Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stained smear showing black-colored cysts resembling crushed ping pong balls are suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). It is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii and occurs at a CD4+ count <200/µl.

Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic fungus causing pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals. It has three morphological forms: trophozoite, pre-cyst and cyst. The infection is transmitted through respiratory droplets. Patients present with fever, non-productive cough and progressive dyspnea. Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The classic finding of dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

It can be diagnosed by demonstration of the organism in broncho-alveolar lavage or lung biopsy specimens. PCR can also be done. Treatment of choice is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and pentamidine isethionate. Cotrimoxazole can also be used for prophylaxis in patients with AIDS.

The following X-ray image shows a cyst (arrow) and bilateral lung infiltrates in a patient with PCP:

Note: Toxoplasma gondii is an opportunistic infection causing encephalitis. On GMS staining of infected tissue, tachyzoites appear as crescent-shaped structures with blue cytoplasm and dark nucleus. Toxoplasmosis typically occurs in AIDS patients with a CD4+ count <100/µl.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy with rheumatic fever developed carditis which subsequently healed in a couple of weeks. How long will you administer benzathine penicillin G for secondary prophylaxis to him?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, benzathine penicillin G for secondary prophylaxis should be given for 10 years from the last attack i.e, till 26 years of age. The given case is of rheumatic fever with carditis but with no residual valvular disease, for which secondary prophylaxis is given for 10 years from the last attack or till 21 years of age, whichever is longer. 

Recommendations for the duration of secondary prophylaxis with penicillin:

Category of the patient

Duration of prophylaxis

Rheumatic fever without carditis

For 5 years after the last attack or until 21 years of age ( whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with carditis but with no residual valvular disease

For 10 years after the last attack or until 21 yrs of age (whichever is longer)

Rheumatic fever with persistent valvular disease evident clinically or on echo

For 10 years after the last attack or until 40 years of age, or sometimes lifelong prophylaxis

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient is being evaluated for uncontrolled hypertension despite being on 3 antihypertensive drugs. He has a history of myocardial infarction which was managed with percutaneous intervention last month. On examination, an abdominal bruit is noted. Lab values indicate elevated serum urea and creatinine. Which of the following investigations is the gold standard test to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of renal artery stenosis. Renal intra-arterial angiography is the gold standard for diagnosis.In a patient with hypertension and increased creatinine, an ultrasound of the abdomen must be performed first to visualize the renal size and morphology to look for a unilateral shrunken kidney and thereby renal artery stenosis. 

Option A: MR angiography is less preferred as gadolinium contrast can lead to nephrogenic fibrosis, particularly in patients with reduced kidney function.

Option C: CT scan with image reconstruction provides an excellent image but also carries a risk of contrast nephropathy.

Option D: Renal arterial doppler ultrasound measures renal artery velocities and can predict hemodynamically important lesions. However, it is not the gold standard test. Duplex ultrasonography is used as a screening investigation.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with fever, pain, and swelling in the left mid-thigh region. X-ray shows lamellated periosteal reaction resembling an onion skin. A biopsy from the lesion is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma.

It is a malignant bone tumor that occurs primarily in children and young adults, in the age group of 10-20 years. It usually affects the long bones, such as the femur, tibia, or humerus. Occasionally, the tumor may begin in the muscles or soft tissues (extraosseous Ewing's sarcoma).

Microscopically, solid sheets of small uniform round cells with PAS-positive magenta pink colored cytoplasm are characteristic of Ewing’s Sarcoma/PNET. The cells show PAS positivity due to the presence of large amounts of cytoplasmic glycogen. This is an important feature for the differential diagnosis of Ewing's with other small round cell tumors.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man was brought to the ED with fever, cough with expectoration, and difficulty in breathing for 1 day. He is a chronic smoker and he has had similar progressive symptoms for the last 4 years. Past PFT findings showed reduced FEV1 and increased RV with normal diffusion capacity. Which of the following is the most common organism implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario gives a picture of acute exacerbation of COPD. The most common bacterial cause of acute COPD exacerbation is Haemophilus influenzae.

Moraxella is the second most common bacterial cause of acute exacerbation of COPD.

questions.text: Which of the following is an activator of the key enzyme required in reverse cholesterol transport?
questions.solution:
Apo A-I is the activator of Lecithin: cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT), the enzyme present in HDL facilitating reverse cholesterol transport.

Lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) is activated by apo A-I which then converts free cholesterol(amphipathic) in HDL to cholesterol ester(hydrophobic). As a result the initial discoidal shape now becomes spherical.

This facilitates reverse cholesterol transport.

Clinical correlation: Familial LCAT deficiency will lead to failure of reverse cholesterol transport resulting in cholesterol deposition in specific peripheral tissues - the cornea, kidneys, and erythrocytes. Major complications include premature atherosclerosis, renal failure, anemia and corneal opacities. HDL cholesterol level is decreased.

questions.text: In a middle-aged diabetic patient with chronic kidney disease stage 5, which of the following drugs can be given safely without altering the dose?
questions.solution:
Linagliptin can be given safely without altering the dose for this patient.

Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl-peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor and is eliminated by the hepatobiliary route. Hence no dosage adjustment is needed in renal failure.

It is used in type 2 diabetes as monotherapy or as combination therapy with other drugs when metformin is not tolerated or contraindicated.

Other DPP-4 inhibitors like sitagliptin, vildagliptin, saxagliptin, alogliptin show renal elimination.

questions.text: Of all the nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors, the use of which of the following is most strongly associated with fat wasting?
questions.solution: Of all the nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors, the use of stavudine is most strongly associated with fat wasting (lipoatrophy).

questions.text: The catalytic efficiency of enzyme is best expressed by which of the following kinetic constants:
questions.solution:
The catalytic efficiency of an enzyme is expressed as Kcat/Km.

Kcat is the rate constant, which is the limiting rate of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction at saturation. It is given by Vmax divided by number of active sites of the enzyme. Km is the Michaelis-Menten constant, which is defined as the substrate concentration at which the initial velocity(Vi) is half the maximum velocity (Vmax/2).

For some enzymes, when a substrate (S) binds to the active site of the enzyme (E), and forms an enzyme-substrate complex (ES), the product is instantaneously formed. For such enzymes, the reaction of E+S→ES becomes the rate-limiting step. Its rate is determined on the rate of diffusion of the molecules in a solution. Hence, these enzymes are called diffusion-limited or catalytically perfect.

Examples of the catalytically perfect enzymes, where the catalytic efficiency reaches the diffusion limit of 108-109 M−1s−1:

  • Triosephosphate isomerase
  • Carbonic anhydrase
  • Acetylcholinesterase
  • Adenosine deaminase

questions.text: A duplex ultrasound was done on a patient with varicose veins. It revealed incompetence of the perforator connecting the great saphenous vein to the superficial femoral vein. What is this perforator known as?
questions.solution:
Dodd’s perforator connects the great saphenous vein to the superficial femoral veins. It is also known as ‘above knee’ perforator and is seen at the inferior ⅓ of the thigh. 

Perforating veins connect the superficial venous system to the deep venous system by penetrating the fascial layers of the lower extremity. Although the total number of perforator veins is variable, up to 100 have been documented.

Named perforators:

  • Adductor Canal (thigh) – Hunter's perforator
  • Above Knee – Dodd's  perforator
  • Below Knee – Boyd's perforator
  • Medial Calf – Cockett I, II, and III perforator
  • Ankle - May or Kustner perforator

questions.text: Hypoxia-induced factors stimulate ___________ cells of the kidney to initiate erythropoiesis.
questions.solution:
Hypoxia induced factors stimulate interstitial cells to initiate erythropoiesis

Erythropoietin is produced by interstitial cells in the peritubular capillary bed of the kidney.

Erythropoietin inturn initiates erythropoiesis

William G. Kaelin Jr., Sir Peter J. Ratcliffe and Gregg L. Semenza won the 2019 Nobel Prize in physiology or medicine. The trio identified molecular machinery that regulates the activity of genes in response to varying levels of oxygen. Their work paved the path for new strategies to fight anemia, cancer and many other diseases.

questions.text: In patients with Madelung deformity, which of the following bones is involved?
questions.solution:
The distal radius is involved in Madelung deformity.

This is a congenital or post-traumatic deformity in children due to disruption of the ulnar and volar aspect of the growth plate of the distal radius. This disruption is believed to be caused by the Vicker's ligament. This ligament normally tethers the lunate to the distal radius proximal to the physis.  

Disruption of the growth plate causes a ventral curvature of the distal radius. However, the ulna continues to grow and the distal ulna appears more prominent may stick out as a lump on the back of the wrist. This is known as a positive ulnar variance. There is volar subluxation of the hand.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl, who is taking antiepileptics, has had a seizure-free period of 6 months. She has no family history of epilepsy. Her EEG is now normal and she has a normal neurological exam and intelligence. What would your advice be?

choices.text: Stop the treatment and follow up
Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a girl on antiepileptics for 6 months with no further seizures, no family history, normal EEG, neurological examination, and intelligence, antiepileptics should be continued for another 18 months since she’s already taken for 6 months (minimum 2 years) to prevent seizure recurrence.

Anti-epileptic drugs withdrawal is considered only when an adult patient has been seizure-free for ≥2 years along with the following criteria:

  • Normal CNS examination including intelligence
  • Normal EEG and normal MRI
  • Single seizure type
  • No family history of epilepsy.

It is preferable to reduce the dose of the drug gradually over 2–3 months.

Other options:

Option A: Sudden cessation of drug therapy may cause recurrence of seizure hence not advised.

Option B: The patient has a seizure-free interval of only 6 months and therefore, is not yet eligible for considering medication withdrawal.

Option D: Life-long treatment is not necessary in this case as the patient meets all the above-mentioned criteria for drug withdrawal after 2 years.

Note: Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME), the most common idiopathic generalized epilepsy syndrome is known to have a high risk of seizure recurrence, and hence antiepileptics are continued lifelong in a majority of patients.

questions.text: An adnexal mass seen on ultrasound in a 38-year-old woman was diagnosed to be a secondary broad ligament fibroid. Which of the following is true about the same?

choices.text: It arises from the broad ligament
The uterine vessels always lie medial to it
The ureter always lies lateral to it
It is also known as true broad ligament fibroid

questions.solution:
The ureter and uterine vessels lie lateral to a secondary broad ligament fibroid.

There are 2 types of broad ligament fibroids:

Primary broad ligament fibroid:

  • It is also known as true broad ligament fibroid.
  • The arise from:
    • Uterosacral ligament
    • Round ligament
    • Tissues in the broad ligament
  • Relations:
    • The uterine vessels lie medial to it.
    • The ureter is usually beneath the fibroid. However, it can be present anywhere in relation to it.

Secondary broad ligament fibroid:

  • It is also known as false broad ligament fibroid.
  • They arise from the lateral wall of the uterus or cervix, but grow laterally, between the two layers of the broad ligament.
  • Relations - the uterine vessels and ureter lie lateral to it.

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal congestion and the following test is performed. Which of the following does not contribute to the boundaries of the involved structure?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Cottle's test being performed and the structure involved is the nasal valve. 

Middle turbinate does not contribute to the boundaries of the nasal valve.

In Cottle's test, the cheek of the patient is drawn laterally during quiet breathing. If this improves the airway on the test side, the test is considered to be positive. This suggests an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve causing nasal obstruction.

  • Laterally: Lower border of upper lateral cartilage and fibrofatty tissue and anterior end of inferior turbinate
  • Medially: Cartilaginous nasal septum
  • Caudally: Floor of the pyriform aperture

The nasal valve is the narrowest part and offers maximum resistance to airflow

questions.text: During the evaluation of a patient with erectile dysfunction, his internal pudendal artery was found to be stenosed. Which of the following​ vessels is this a branch of?

choices.text: Anterior division of internal iliac artery
Posterior division of internal iliac artery

questions.solution:
The anterior division of the internal iliac artery gives rise to the internal pudendal artery.

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

Branches of the anterior trunk of internal iliac artery:

  • Obturator artery

questions.text: A woman came to the clinic complaining of amenorrhoea and inability to conceive. She had undergone hypophysectomy for a tumour a year ago. What would be the best line of management for her?

choices.text: Human menopausal gonadotrophin, followed by hCG

questions.solution:
The best line of management for the given patient is human menopausal gonadotropin (hMG) followed by hCG.

The patients who have undergone hypophysectomy i.e. removal of the pituitary gland, can not produce endogenous gonadotropins. Exogenous gonadotropins such as hMG are given to such patients. Timed administration of hCG is needed to induce ovulation after the follicle has matured.

The human menopausal gonadotropin is an extract of urine from postmenopausal women. It contains FSH and LH in the required ratio for follicular growth.

Clomiphene, letrozole, and GnRH analogs stimulate the release of gonadotropins from the pituitary gland. These are not helpful in a patient whose pituitary gland has been removed.

questions.text: Where are Paltauf’s hemorrhages seen?
questions.solution:
Paltauf's hemorrhages are seen in the lungs as subpleural hemorrhages.

They are found when the alveolar walls rupture as a result of increased pressure during forced expirations. They are described in 50–60% of drownings.

questions.text: An alcohol addict presented with easy fatiguability. On examination, he is found to have pallor. Peripheral smear showed macrocytes and anisocytosis. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anemia likely due to folate deficiency caused by alcohol addiction. Folate deficiency leads to atrophic glossitis because of damage to the epithelial surfaces.

Option B: Migratory glossitis / geographic tongue is due to rapid loss and regrowth of filiform papillae of the tongue. It is a benign inflammatory condition of the tongue associated with psoriasis and reactive arthritis.

Option C: Strawberry tongue is due to the hypertrophy of fungiform papillae. It is seen in scarlet fever and Kawasaki disease.

Option D: Macroglossia is an abnormal enlargement of the tongue and can be congenital or acquired. New-onset macroglossia in adults is highly suggestive of amyloidosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with bipolar disorder comes to the clinic for a routine follow-up. His condition was difficult to control and required treatment with multiple medications over the past two years. The patient says his mood has been stable with his current regimen, but for the past three months, he has had tremors primarily affecting his hands. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Lithium carbonate is most likely to cause the tremors described in the given scenario.

Tremors are a common adverse effect of lithium carbonate. They are sometimes related to peak serum lithium levels.

Dividing the dose of lithium carbonate and decreasing caffeine intake can decrease the severity of the tremors. In case of severe coarse tremors, lithium carbonate toxicity (serum lithium level greater than 2.5 mEq/L) must be ruled out.

Options A and C: Carbamazepine and lamotrigine are off-label agents used for the management of bipolar disorder, however, they do not cause tremors.

Option B: Tremors may occur as an adverse effect of gabapentin, but it is not prescribed for the management of bipolar disorder.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was brought by his wife to the psychiatric OPD. She complaints that he does not allow her to discard old newspapers and informs that their home is completely disorganized because of this accumulation. She also says that he fights with her if she tries to discard them. On asking the husband, he replies that he has an attachment towards them. He gets anxious by the thought of discarding the newspapers as he may lose some precious information. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hoarding disorder in the patient.

Hoarding disorder is characterized by the persistent and profound difficulty in discarding or parting from one’s possessions. This, in turn, leads to significant congestion and clutter, and to substantial distress or impairment (this differentiates hoarding disorder from normal collecting). 

Obsessive-compulsive disorder Hoarding disorder
Here, hoarding is done because of an obsessive thought. No obsession present
Here, hoarding is done to relieve the anxiety caused by the obsession. Here, hoarding is done because the individual wishes to save things and feels anxious to discard the things.

questions.text: A young patient presents with a history of itchy hypopigmented patches over her upper back which she noticed after joining a swim team. A KOH mount is prepared with the skin scraping sample, which on microscopy reveals a characteristic appearance as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with hypopigmented patches and the KOH mount preparation showing a spaghetti and meatball appearance suggests a diagnosis of pityriasis versicolor.

Pityriasis versicolor is a chronic superficial infection of the stratum corneum caused by Malassezia globosa and Malassezia furfur. The most common site involves the neck, chest, back, and upper arms. The lesions often appear as hypopigmented areas.

The KOH mount reveals fungal hyphae that are short and thick (like spaghetti or banana) and many variously sized spores (like meatballs or grapes) referred to as spaghetti and meatballs or bananas and grapes appearance.

Treatment includes topical azoles or selenium sulfide for 2 weeks.

The image below shows the hypopigmented lesions of P. versicolour over the chest.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with left knee pain, redness, and swelling for 3 days. Joint aspiration is performed and microscopic findings under polarised light are given in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease (CPPD), also known as pseudo-gout and chondrocalcinosis.

The image shows aspirated crystals which are rhomboid, 0.5 to 5 μm in the greatest dimension, and positively birefringent (yellow). 

It usually occurs in individuals older than 50 years of age and becomes more common with old age.

CPPD is classified into sporadic (idiopathic), hereditary, and secondary types. It is caused by germline mutations in the pyrophosphate transport channel. The secondary form is associated with

  • Previous joint damage
  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Ochronosis
  • Diabetes 

Inflammation is usually milder than in gout. CPPD may produce acute, subacute, or chronic arthritis that can be confused with osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis. The joint involvement may be monoarticular or polyarticular; the knees, followed by the wrists, elbows, shoulders, and ankles, are most commonly affected.

questions.text: Which of the following metals can be detected even in conflagrated human remains?
questions.solution:
Arsenic can be detected even in conflagrated human bones. Hence, it is possible to detect poisoning by arsenic even when the body has been burnt for a long time.

Arsenic is volatile but much of the arsenic in bones is converted into arsenates, which are non-volatile. 

In suspected cases of poisoning by arsenic, all the available ashes and burnt bones should be preserved for chemical analysis.

questions.text: Which of the following heart sounds would be normal in pregnancy?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A patient is unable to hold a piece of paper between his thumb and index finger firmly following a cut wound over the hypothenar eminence. Which of the following nerves is likely to be damaged?

choices.text: Superficial terminal branch of ulnar nerve

questions.solution:
Loss of adduction points toward the deep ulnar nerve injury. The hypothenar injury could have caused downstream loss of innervation of the deep ulnar nerve which innervates adductor pollicis in thenar eminence.

The course of deep ulnar nerve:

  • At its origin, it innervates the hypothenar muscles.
  • As it crosses the deep part of the hand, it innervates all the interosseous muscles and the third and fourth lumbricals.
  • It ends by innervating the adductor pollicis and the medial (deep) head of the flexor pollicis brevis. 
  • It also sends articular filaments to the wrist joint following Hilton's law.

questions.text: A 76 year-old female presented with a non-healing ulcer on the labia majora for a period of 6 months, measuring 2 cm x 3 cm. No lymph nodes were palpable. Biopsy shows squamous cell carcinoma. How do you manage this case?

choices.text: Total vulvectomy with unilateral LN dissection
Partial vulvectomy with ipsilateral inguinofemoral  LN dissection

questions.solution:
According to the recent FIGO guidelines,the patient’s lesion measuring 2 cm x 3 cm with no palpable lymph nodes falls under stage Ib vulval cancer and it's management is partial vulvectomy with ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection.

For stage IB cancers, radical partial vulvectomy is recommended for the primary tumor and as the women with stage IB cancer can have diseased lymph nodes even without palpable enlargement of nodes, Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy (SLNB) and/ inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy is performed.

Ipsilateral dissection of lymph nodes is performed if the vulvar lesion is present laterally, >2cm beyond the midline. In cases where the vulvar lesion lies within 2 cm from the midline, bilateral inguinofemoral Lymph Node dissection will be performed.

In this patient, the best management would be to perform Partial vulvectomy with ipsilateral inguinofemoral LN dissection among the given options.

questions.text: A 30-year old woman is on chronic therapy with the anti-TB drug Isoniazid. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is likely to develop in this individual?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid, a drug used to treat tuberculosis, can induce a vitamin B6 deficiency.

Isoniazid is the first-line antitubercular drug that inhibits the production of mycolic acid. It is a bactericidal drug against tubercle bacilli. Important side effects of isoniazid include peripheral neuritis, hepatitis, anemia, rashes, and arthralgia.

Peripheral neuritis occurs due to interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine. Patients present with clinical features of pyridoxine/vitamin B6 deficiency, which include paresthesias, numbness, and tingling sensation.

The most widely used method to know the vitamin B6 nutritional status is by measuring the RBC transaminase activity, by adding pyridoxal phosphate in vitro. Direct measurement of the plasma concentrations of the vitamin (pyridoxal phosphate) can also be done.

Therefore, 10 mg/day of pyridoxine is given prophylactically along with isoniazid to prevent neurotoxicity.
