questions.text: A patient has been on lisinopril since being diagnosed with hypertension last year. His blood pressure readings are quite high, and the doctor considers adding a diuretic. Which amongst the following would be the ideal add on drug?
questions.solution:
Hydrochlorothiazide would be the ideal add-on drug. It is a thiazide diuretic and causes hypokalemia, which can counteract the hyperkalemia caused by lisinopril, an ACE inhibitor.

Aldosterone causes Na+ absorption in the collecting duct and the distal tubule in exchange for H+ and K+. ACE inhibitors decrease angiotensin II levels and thereby, decrease aldosterone levels. Decreased aldosterone level causes K+ retention by reducing the exchange. Therefore, ACE inhibitors cause retention of K+.

Diuretics that cause elevation of plasma K+ levels are not suitable for combining with ACE inhibitors.

Potassium-sparing diuretics like spironolactone, eplerenone, and amiloride are contraindicated with ACE inhibitors.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with benign prostatic hypertrophy underwent TURP.  An hour later, he was found to have an altered sensorium and had several bouts of vomiting. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The most probable cause for the above-mentioned symptoms is water intoxication also known as transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) syndrome. 

Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of transurethral urethral resection can lead to :

  • Hyponatremia, which may manifest as confusion, nausea, and vomiting
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Hemolysis 

It is managed by fluid restriction.

The use of isotonic glycine for irrigation during resection reduces the incidence of water intoxication.

questions.text: A child in your unit is admitted with alopecia, oligodontia, and features of rickets with elevated serum levels of alkaline phosphatase activity and 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D. What could be the pathology?
questions.solution:
Alopecia and oligodontia (reduced number of teeth) with features of rickets in a child is classically seen in vitamin D-dependant rickets type 2 where the pathology is end-organ resistance (receptor hyposensitivity) to vitamin D.

Rickets causes

  • Nutritional vitamin D deficiency
  • Secondary vitamin D deficiency
    • Vitamin D-dependant rickets, type 1 (defect in 1-alpha hydroxylase)
    • Vitamin D-dependant rickets, type 2 (end organ resistance)
    • Chronic kidney disease
  • Hypophosphatemic rickets
    • X-linked dominant hypophosphatemic rickets (PHEX gene mutation)
    • Autosomal dominant (fibroblast growth factor [FGF] resistance to endopeptidases)
    • Oncogenous rickets (increased FGF 23)

Note:

Vitamin D antibodies are found in most patients of systemic sclerosis.

Related Pearl: Vitamin D activation and Rickets

questions.text: A basketball player presented to the casualty with severe pain in his wrist. He sustained a fall on his flexed wrist during a match. Examination revealed tenderness and painful dorsiflexion of his wrist. An X-ray of his wrist showed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph reveals a distal radial fracture that extends into the intra-articular region. This is known as Barton's fracture. In this case, the dorsal segment is fractured, and therefore, this is a dorsal Barton's fracture. 

Conservative treatment involves applying a short arm cast with the wrist in the neutral position. Surgical management is by open reduction and internal fixation with percutaneous pins or small plates and screws.

Reverse (volar) Barton's fracture is an articular fracture of the distal radius with dislocation in which the articular surface of the radius remains in contact with the carpus; however, the reverse type involves the volar portion rather than the dorsal aspect of the radius.

Conservative management is with a long-arm cast. Surgical fixation with K- wires, external fixators, and buttress plates are considered if the reduction is not properly retained. Ellis-T-shaped buttress plate fixation is preferred.

The below images shows reverse (volar) Barton's fracture. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman was brought in a dehydrated state and complains of loose stools. On examination, a tender neck swelling was found which was found to be present for 1 year. Histopathology of the swelling shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Histopathology shows the presence of amyloid deposits that are derived from the altered calcitonin molecules.

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumor of parafollicular or C cells of the thyroid gland. They are derived from the neural crest cells of the ultimobranchial bodies. 

Most of the MTCs occur sporadically. However, around a quarter of the cancers are associated with familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B.

Patients with sporadic MTC present at an older age, whereas patients with familial MTC usually present at a younger age. Features of MTC include:

  • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia or dyspnea if locally invaded
  • Diarrhoea due to increased intestinal motility by serotonin
  • Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production
  • Metastasis is blood-borne
  • Microscopically, they consist of sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloid stroma

It is diagnosed by careful family history, physical examination, raised calcitonin, CEA levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass.

Total thyroidectomy with central neck node dissection is the treatment of choice in MTC patients. External beam radiotherapy can be used in patients with unresectable tumors. Targeted therapy can be considered using vandetanib, sorafenib, sunitinib, and cabozantinib.

Prophylactic total thyroidectomy should be considered within 5years of age in MEN2A mutation and within 1year of age in MEN2B mutation.

questions.text: A young boy was rushed to the emergency room with complaints of respiratory distress and high-grade fever. The microscopy and culture of the sputum showed gram-positive cocci with α-hemolytic activity on blood agar. Which of the following antibiotics is the pathogen most likely susceptible to?
questions.solution:
Sputum showing gram-positive cocci with α-hemolytic activity in a patient with high-grade fever and respiratory distress is suggestive of pneumococcal pneumonia. Pneumococci show optochin susceptibility.

Both Streptococcus pneumoniae and Streptococcus viridans produce α-hemolysis on blood agar. The optochin sensitivity test is done to differentiate Streptococcus pneumoniae from commensal-like viridans Streptococci.

The image given below shows the classification of gram-positive bacteria.

Optochin sensitivity is observed using the disc diffusion method.

The image given below shows a sensitivity testing plate of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presented with the following lesion in his eye. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image depicts Bitot's spot, a pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia. Hence, the likely diagnosis in this 21-year-old man presenting with the above lesion is xerophthalmia.

Bitot's spot is a triangular, silvery-white, foamy patch on the bulbar conjunctiva which is usually bilateral. The most common site is temporal.

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows a rectal temperature probe.

Option B: NAVA is Neurally Adjusted Ventilatory Assist is a mode of mechanical ventilation. The NAVA catheter detects electrical activity signalling on the diaphragm.

Option C: Swan Ganz catheter / Pulmonary artery catheter is used for right heart catheterization.

Option D: A CVP transducer is used in critical care settings to monitor the central venous pressure. It is connected to a central venous line and a monitor.

questions.text: A patient developed the following lesions after 10 days of initiation of chemotherapy. The patient also complains of similar lesions over soles and they are sensitive to touch. Which is the most likely agent to cause this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts classical findings of hand-foot syndrome and capecitabine is commonly associated with this prominent side effect.

Hand foot syndrome or palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia consists of erythema, desquamation, pain and sensitivity to touch of the palms and soles. 

Drugs commonly implicated are:

  • Capecitabine
  • 5-Fluorouracil
  • Cytarabine
  • Pemetrexed
  • Doxorubicin

questions.text: A 10-year-old child came with complaints of pain over the right lower quadrant and lower back pain. On examination, the patient had pain over the right side of the hip on passive extension with a mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of lower back pain, mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin and pain on passive extension of the ipsilateral hip is suggestive of a psoas abscess. 

Psoas abscess is a retroperitoneal abscess, caused due to various etiologies. Previously, tuberculosis of the spine was the most common cause secondary to spreading infection from the digestive or urinary tract, which can cause psoas abscess. Nowadays, Crohn’s disease is the most common cause. Patients present with flank pain, fever and chills, malaise and weight loss. They can have referred pain to the hip, groin or knee. When the swelling extends across the groin and below the inguinal ligament along the course of the iliopsoas, it becomes cross fluctuant across the inguinal ligament.

Imaging is done by a CT scan, which shows a low-density mass with surrounding inflammation and infiltration of surrounding fat and gas or air-fluid levels.

Treatment is done by percutaneous CT-guided drainage and appropriate antibiotics.

Other options:

Option A: Pyelonephritis is usually associated with a history of urinary tract infection and sudden onset of pain in the flank and hypochondrium, not the lumbar region.

Option C: Appendicitis (retrocaecal) can present with pain on passive extension of the hip (psoas sign), but the presence of a mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin makes it an unlikely diagnosis.

Option D: Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency condition presenting with sudden onset pain in the scrotum, groin and lower abdomen, tenderness, redness and edema of the scrotal skin.

questions.text: A patient sustains an injury to the lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus in the right hemisphere. Loss of sensation is likely to be seen at which of the following sites in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case, injury to the lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus in the right hemisphere would result in loss of sensation in the left facial area.

Each hemisphere receives somatic sensory information from the opposite side of the body in the postcentral gyrus (somatosensory area).

The lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus receives somatic sensory information from the facial and neck region while the medial portion of the postcentral gyrus received somatic sensory information from the trunk and appendages.

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of a child who presented with stridor. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of a retropharyngeal abscess. It can be diagnosed on a lateral x-ray of the soft tissues of the neck.  The features include :

  • Widening of the prevertebral soft tissue shadow
  • Loss of cervical lordosis
  • In an acute abscess,  air-fluid levels can be seen.

questions.text: Which cytokine is an important growth factor for plasma cells in multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
The proliferation and survival of plasma cells are dependent on several cytokines, most notably IL-6.

It is an important growth factor for plasma cells. It is produced by the tumor cells themselves and by resident marrow stromal cells. IL6, along with other cytokines, promotes osteoclastic activity and lytic bone lesions. High serum levels of IL-6 are seen in patients with active disease and are associated with a poor prognosis.

questions.text: A patient has been bitten by a snake and the relatives have brought the snake with them. Which of the following findings will assure you that the snake is non-poisonous?
questions.solution:
Incomplete belly scales are usually seen in non-poisonous snakes.

In poisonous snakes, belly scales are large and cover the entire belly.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with a single hypoaesthetic and a hypopigmented patch on the lateral aspect of the forearm. Microscopy of a biopsy sample from the lesion revealed granulomatous inflammation but acid-fast bacilli were not identified. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is tuberculoid leprosy.

On microscopic examination, tuberculoid leprosy has granulomatous lesions closely resembling those found in tuberculosis. Because of the strong host defense, bacilli are almost never found, hence the name paucibacillary leprosy.

Leprosy or Hansen disease is a slowly progressive infection caused by Mycobacterium leprae, mainly affecting the skin and peripheral nerves.

questions.text: While assisting in the caesarean section of a multigravida, you see the senior obstetrician using the following instrument. Identify it.
questions.solution:
The given instrument is Green-Armytage forceps.

Its tips are broad and hence can compress a wide area. During lower segment caesarean section (LSCS), these forceps are applied at the bleeding cut uterine edges for hemostasis.

questions.text: An infant with a history of delayed separation of the umbilical cord now presents with recurrent pneumonia. The total leukocyte count is 20,000/microlitre. Which of the following genetic defects is most likely present?

choices.text: Mutation of Bruton tyrosine kinase gene
Low levels of NADPH oxidase and negative DHR test
Reduced phagocyte surface expression of sialyl-Lewis x
Excessive IgM with reduced IgG and IgA

questions.solution:
This history of delayed separation of the umbilical cord with recurrent pneumonia and peripheral leucocytosis is highly suggestive of leucocyte adhesion defect (LAD). In this defect, there is reduced phagocyte surface expression of sialyl-Lewis X. 

LAD is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting leukocyte function. Neutrophils have reduced adhesion, mobility, and phagocytic ability. There are three main types of LAD:

  • LAD 1- Defective β2 integrin common chain (CD18), leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and defective tight adhesion. 
  • LAD 2- Reduced phagocyte surface expression of sialyl-Lewis X (fucosylated protein), leading to abnormal neutrophil rolling and tethering. 
  • LAD 3- Defect in regulatory protein (kindlin 3, also known as Fermt 3) involved in activating the ligand affinity for β2 integrins, leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion (milder than type 1). 

LAD is characterised by recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, reduced inflammatory responses despite elevated blood neutrophilia, and delayed wound healing and delayed umbilical cord loss. in patients with LAD type 3, there may be bleeding as β2 integrin on platelets is non-functional.

Typical signs of inflammation may be absent, pus does not form with few neutrophils on biopsy of infected tissues along with massive hyperleukocytosis (>30,000/μL) in the blood. Early allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is used in the treatment of severe LAD.

questions.text: A researcher decided to use double-blinding in his trial evaluating two new therapies for cystic fibrosis. What is the characteristic feature of this concept?

choices.text: Study and control groups are blinded
Observer and group being observed are blinded
Group members and analyzer are blinded

questions.solution:
In double-blind trials, both the group members (study and control group) and the observers are not aware of the group allocation.

Related Pearl: Blinding in Epidemiology

  • Blinding is done in epidemiology to reduce the possibility of bias.
  • Types:
    • In single blind trials, only the participants or group members are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In double blind trials, both the group members and the observers are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In triple blind trials, the group members, the observers and the analyzers are unaware of the group allocation.
  • The most commonly used type of blinding is double blinding.

questions.text: What will be the level of the anti-Mullerian hormone in low ovarian reserve?
questions.solution:
In low ovarian reserve, the level of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) will be <1 ng/ml. 

AMH is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of the primordial follicle of the ovary. It helps in oocyte maturation and mono-follicular development. AMH is also used in assessing ovarian reserve.

AMH levels in ng/ml Interpretation
2–6.8 Normal
<1 Poor ovarian reserve
>10

PCOD

Hyperstimulation syndrome

In women, AMH is always absent during embryogenesis and is secreted by the granulosa cells after puberty. It helps in follicular development and oocyte maturation. Estimation of serum AMH is used in the study of ovarian reserve in female infertility and secondary amenorrhoea.

In men, AMH starts to be secreted by the Sertoli cells in the testes by the 7th week of intrauterine life. It continues until puberty. It inhibits the development of the Müllerian system. The absence of AMH results in the development of hermaphroditism.

questions.text: A patient came to casualty complaining of a severe headache. On examination, there was no focal neurological defect. However, neck rigidity was present. The casualty medical officer ordered an emergency CT which revealed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH).

The most common cause of SAH is trauma. The most common spontaneous cause of SAH is the rupture of berry aneurysms.

It clinically presents as a thunderclap headache with neck rigidity, transient loss of consciousness and no focal neurological deficit. Non-contrast CT shows blood in the basal cistern.

Although sudden headache in the absence of focal neurological symptoms is the hallmark of aneurysmal rupture, focal neurological deficits may occur. Hess and Hunt's scale is the most widely used scale to grade the severity of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

The definitive management of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is done surgically by craniotomy and clipping or by endovascular embolization known as coiling. This prevents rebleeding of the aneurysm.

questions.text: The instrument shown below will be least useful for examining patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a proctoscope. It is not used for examining patients with anal fissures. 

Due to pain, digital rectal examination and anoscopy are not performed immediately in an acute anal fissure. It is reserved for later when the symptoms resolve or the patient is in the operating room.

Proctoscopy is indicated in patients with the following:

  • Rectal bleeding
  • Change in bowel habit, especially recurring attacks of diarrhea
  • Pain or difficulty in defecation
  • Lesions around the anal opening - abscesses, fistulae, discharge, ulcers, external hemorrhoids
  • Rectal prolapse.

questions.text: What is the rate of blood flow in the hemodialysis machine?
questions.solution: During hemodialysis, heparinized blood flows through the dialyzer at a rate of 250–450 mL/min. On the other hand, the dialysate flows in the opposite counter-current direction at 500–800 mL/min.

questions.text: A middle-aged man came with a history of fever and night sweats for the past 2 weeks. He has had noticeable weight loss. Bronchoalveolar lavage was done, but Mycobacterium tuberculosis was not detected. Extra-pulmonary TB is suspected. Which site is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Lymph nodes are the most common site of extrapulmonary TB.

The diagnosis is established by fine needle aspiration biopsy. 

In descending order of frequency, the extrapulmonary sites most commonly involved in TB are:

  • lymph nodes
  • pleura
  • genitourinary tract
  • bones and joints
  • meninges, peritoneum and pericardium. 

In less than 50% of these cases, there is associated pulmonary disease.

questions.text: An unimmunized man presents with fever, malaise, and an erythematous rash starting from behind the ears and progressing to the face and trunk. Given below is an image of lymphoid tissue taken from this patient. What pathological finding do you see here?
questions.solution:
Fever, malaise, and an erythematous rash starting from behind the ears and progressing to the face and trunk suggest a diagnosis of measles. Warthin-Finkeldey cells are the multinucleate giant cells shown in the image above, found in the lymphoid tissues of patients with measles.

The measles virus is an enveloped ssRNA virus belonging to the paramyxovirus family. Its cytopathic effect consists of multinucleate syncytium formation with numerous acidophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions, as shown in the image below.

Measles has a prodromal phase characterised by fever, coryza, redness of the eyes, Koplik spots (bluish-white ulcerations on the buccal mucosa), and lymphopenia. This phase is followed by the development of a maculopapular rash that starts behind the ears and progresses downwards. Complications of measles include pneumonia, acute encephalitis and sub-sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE).  

Other options: 

Option B: Touton giant cells are seen in fat necrosis, xanthomas, xanthogranulomas and dermatofibroma.

Option C: Langhans giant cells are seen in tuberculosis. 

Option D: Aschoff giant cells are seen in rheumatic fever.

Related Pearl: Cytopathic effects caused by viruses

questions.text: A medical student skipped breakfast to be able to attend his morning class. He is currently thinking about having food and coffee after class, and notices increased salivary secretion. The nerve fibres to the parotid gland responsible for this come from all except:
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of parasympathetic stimulation of the salivary glands, causing the parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to increase salivary secretion.

The parasympathetic fibres to the parotid gland are carried by the lesser petrosal nerve.

Otic ganglion is a parasympathetic ganglion which supplies secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland and is present below the foramen ovale. 

  • Preganglionic fibres originate in the inferior salivatory nucleus and pass through the lesser petrosal nerve which is the continuation of the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve. They relay in the otic ganglion.
  • Postganglionic fibres pass by the communicating branches to the auriculotemporal nerve and supply the parotid gland.

The greater petrosal nerve carries secretomotor fibres to the pterygopalatine ganglion and supplies the lacrimal, nasal, and palatine glands.

Sympathetic supply to the parotid gland is derived from the plexus around the middle meningeal artery.

Sensory supply to the parotid gland is from the auriculotemporal nerve and to the parotid capsule is from the sensory fibres of greater auricular nerve.

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty with fever with chills and chest pain. He also gives history of passing brown-colored urine. He was prescribed an antimicrobial drug for urinary tract infection three days ago and his symptoms began after he had started this medication. Which of the following antimicrobial agents had most likely been prescribed?
questions.solution:
The patient had most likely been prescribed nitrofurantoin as the scenario depicts side effects of this drug.

Nitrofurantoin is a urinary antiseptic used against lower UTI caused by E.coli and enterococci. Its use results in brown urine. It is also associated with acute pneumonitis with fever, chills, cough, dyspnea, chest pain, pulmonary infiltration, and eosinophilia within hours to days of initiation of therapy. The symptoms resolve quickly after discontinuation of the drug.

The antibacterial activity of nitrofurantoin is due to its intracellular conversion to highly reactive intermediates by bacterial reductases. These intermediates react nonspecifically with ribosomal proteins and disrupt the synthesis of proteins, RNA, DNA, and other metabolic processes.

questions.text: A young female patient presents to the clinic with a painless lump in her right breast. She underwent breast augmentation surgery 3 years back. Which of the following will be the best investigation to assess the breast tissue in this patient?
questions.solution:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the best investigation to assess breast tissue in a patient with a breast implant.

MRI of the breast is also used in:

  • Screening of high-risk individuals with a positive family history.
  • Assessing loco-regional spread (multifocality and multicentricity) of carcinoma.
  • To differentiate scar from recurrence in women who have had breast conservation surgery for breast cancer.

Option A: Tomosynthesis is not preferred, as radio-opaque implants are usually compressed together with the breast tissue, obscuring the visibility and thereby reducing its sensitivity.

Option B: Ultrasonography is used as an initial investigation in the evaluation of breast abnormalities in patients with breast implants.

Option D: Computed tomography is not routinely used in the evaluation of breast lumps.

questions.text:
Arrange the coverings of the kidney from within outwards:

1. Renal fascia
2. Fibrous capsule
3. Paranephric fat
4. Perinephric fat
questions.solution:
The 4 coverings of the kidney from within outwards are as follows:

  1. True or fibrous capsule - formed by the collagen-rich connective tissue.
  2. Perinephric fat or adipose capsule - consists of fat and occupies the space between the fibrous capsule and the renal fascia.
  3. Renal fascia
  4. Paranephric fat - occupies the space between the renal fascia and the anterior layer of the thoracolumbar fascia.

questions.text: Diene’s method of staining is used for which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Diene's method is used for mycoplasma.

Mycoplasma are cultured on solid media enriched with 20% horse or human serum and yeast extract. The colonies show a ‘fried-egg’ appearance which is appreciated by Diene’s method of staining. A block of agar containing the colony is cut and placed on a slide and is then covered with a cover slip on which an alcoholic solution of methylene blue and azure has been dried.

Colonies have a central opaque granular dark bluish area, representing the area of mycoplasmal growth into the depth of the medium, and pale flat translucent blue periphery indicating superficial growth of mycoplasma on the agar.

questions.text: Garrod’s tetrad includes all of the following, except ____.
questions.solution:
Phenylketonuria is not a component of Garrod's tetrad.

Garrod’s tetrad includes the following:

  • Alkaptonuria: Due to homogentisate oxidase deficiency
  • Albinism: Due to tyrosinase deficiency
  • Cystinuria: A type of aminoaciduria that prevents proper reabsorption of basic, or positively charged, amino acids that includes cystine, ornithine, lysine and arginine(COLA)
  • Pentosuria: Due to the deficiency of L-xylulose reductase or xylitol dehydrogenase, which are necessary for xylitol metabolism

Garrod's tetrad is named after the British physician Archibald Garrod, who introduced the phrase "inborn error of metabolism" in a lecture in 1908. His insights provided a foundation for the developing field of biochemical genetics.

questions.text: Following a normal vaginal delivery, the placenta delivered by controlled cord traction appeared as shown below. What is this condition known as?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a placenta with a small, accessory lobe. This condition is known as placenta succenturiata. 

A succenturiate placenta contains single or multiple accessory lobes. Accessory lobes are attached to the main lobe by a membrane that has a leash of blood vessels.

Option A: Bilobate placenta - it consists of two placental lobes. The cord inserts between the two lobes.

Option C: Placenta membranacea - entire surface of the fetal membranes are covered by functioning villi and the placenta develops as a thin membranous structure occupying the entire periphery of the chorion.

Option D: Placenta marginata - chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate, and a thin margin is present between the chorionic and basal plates.

Patient X is taking olanzapine which has side effects of weight gain and hypotension.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme action is not affected in a patient with Menke's disease?
questions.solution:
In a patient with Menke's disease, glutathione peroxidase action is not affected.

Menke’s disease, or kinky/steely hair syndrome is an X-linked recessive condition, where there is a mutation in the ATP7A gene. This leads to defective copper-binding P-type ATPase and copper is not mobilized from the intestine. Thus copper deficiency occurs and enzymes containing copper are affected, like superoxide dismutase, dopamine hydroxylase and amine oxidase. 

Glutathione peroxidase is not affected since it requires selenium in the form of selenocysteine.

Other copper deficiency disorders include Wilson's disease and MEDNIK syndrome. Wilson’s disease is an autosomal recessive disorder, due to ATP7B mutation, a gene encoding for copper transporting ATPase in the cells. There is defective biliary copper excretion from liver cells, leading to copper deposits in the liver and brain. MEDNIK syndrome is a rare multisystem disorder of copper metabolism with features of both Wilson’s and Menke’s disease.

Note: 
Other enzymes requiring copper are ferroxidase (ceruloplasmin) , cytochrome c oxidase, tyrosinase (melanin synthesis), lysyl oxidase (cross-linking in collagen). It is also a component of ferroportin, which is involved in iron absorption.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: Milind, a young child is brought to you for recurrent respiratory symptoms and dysphagia. After ruling out other causes, you suspect a vascular anomaly that could be compressing the esophagus to be causing the symptoms. A CECT is done and the findings are as shown below. Which of the following vascular anomalies is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario suggests a diagnosis of dysphagia lusoria, which is caused most likely by the aberrant right subclavian artery. The given image suggests the presence of the right aberrant subclavian artery.

Dysphagia lusoria is dysphagia produced due to extrinsic compression of the oesophagus by a developmental vascular anomaly, often an aberrant right subclavian artery or right-sided or double aortic arch.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady is diagnosed with Hashimoto thyroiditis and a positive antibody titer against thyroid peroxidase enzyme. Which of the following is not a function of the affected enzyme?
questions.solution:
Iodide trapping (iodide uptake) is not catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase. Oxidation, organification, and coupling are catalyzed by it.  

Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone: 

  • Iodide uptake: The basolateral sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) actively takes up I-(iodide) from the circulation into the follicular cells. It is then transported into the colloid through a pendrin (chloride-iodide) transporter 
  • Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin (Tg), is a large glycoprotein rich in tyrosine residues. It is synthesized by follicular cells.
  • Iodination of thyroglobulin: This is regulated by the thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme. TPO has three functions: 
    • Oxidation: TPO oxidizes I- to I2 (iodine)  in the presence of H2O2
    • Organification: TPO links tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin with iodine (I2) to form monoiodotyrosine (MIT), diiodotyrosine (DIT)
    • Coupling reactions: TPO combines iodinated tyrosine residues to make MIT + DIT = T3 (triiodothyronine), DIT + DIT = T4 (tetraiodothyronine)
  • Storage: Thyroid hormones are bound to thyroglobulin and stored in the follicular lumen as colloids. The colloid has hormone reserves for 2-3 months
  • Release: Iodinated thyroglobulin is taken up by the thyroid follicles via endocytosis and fuses with lysosomes. It is cleaved by lysosomal proteolytic enzymes into MIT, DIT, T3, and T4. T4 (80%) and T3 (20%) are released into the blood
  • Peripheral T3 conversion: T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which is the active form of the hormone

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was initiated on haloperidol therapy. 2 days later he presented to the OPD with deviation of his eyes,  asymmetric neck posture and inability to open his mouth completely. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of deviation of the eyes (oculogyric crisis), asymmetric position of the head or neck (torticollis) and inability to open the mouth (trismus) are pointing towards a diagnosis of haloperidol-induced acute dystonia.

These extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) occur due to the antagonism of dopamine D2 receptors.

Acute dystonia is more commonly associated with high potency typical antipsychotics like haloperidol and occurs within 1 to 5 days of initiation of therapy. Benztropine or diphenhydramine may be used for treatment.

The left ventricle has 2 papillary muscles.

questions.text: Baroreceptor stimulation would result in _______
questions.solution:
Baroreceptor stimulation would result in decreased sympathetic discharge to heart.

The baroreceptors are stretch receptors in the walls of the heart and blood vessels. 
Baroreceptor stimulation, by distension of the structures they are located in, inhibits the tonic discharge of sympathetic nerves and excites the vagal innervation of the heart. Thus leading to:

  • Vasodilation and venodilation
  • Hypotension
  • Bradycardia
  • Decrease in cardiac output

questions.text: Identify the organism below that causes effacement and attachment of intestinal cells.
questions.solution:
Attachment and effacement lesions on intestinal cells are caused by enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC).

E. coli is the second most common cause of diarrhea in the pediatric age group. Rotavirus is the most common cause. EPEC causes watery diarrhea which is self-limiting.

EPEC adheres to the mucosal cells of the small bowel and causes loss of microvilli (effacement). This leads to the formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures and occasionally may cause entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells.

 Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors:

  •  Bundle-forming pilus encoded by plasmid containing EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
  •  Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding PET scans?

choices.text: It is used for 2D image reproduction
It can be used for hybrid imaging

questions.solution:
PET or positron emission tomography is a nuclear medicine imaging technique that can be used for hybrid imaging. That is, it can be combined with CT to allow a correlation between the metabolic information (PET) and the cross-sectional anatomic information (CT).

PET scanning measures the uptake of positron-emitting radioisotopes in the body, allowing us to visualize the functional processes of the body. 3D images of tracer concentration within the body are then constructed by computer analysis. Hence, it provides metabolic and functional information, unlike CT and MRI, as it is based on the principle that tumor cells generally have high metabolic activity compared with normal tissues.

A glucose analogue called fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) is used in PET imaging. FDG is taken up by metabolically active cells, where it undergoes phosphorylation to form FDG-6-phosphate. Unlike glucose, FDG-6-phosphate cannot undergo further metabolism and becomes trapped within the cell and this is detected by the PET scanner.

Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) is another similar imaging technique.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man who presented with diarrhea and flushing was found to have an ileal tumor. The histological image of the resected specimen is given below. Which of the following markers will these cells be positive for?
questions.solution:
The given history and histological image are diagnostic of ileal carcinoid. The tumor cells are typically positive for synaptophysin on immunohistochemistry.

Histology of carcinoid typically reveals islands and nests of uniform cells with scant, pink granular cytoplasm and salt and pepper chromatin. Electron microscopy reveals cytoplasmic dense-core neurosecretory granules.

Carcinoid tumors most commonly occur in the gastrointestinal tract. The most common sites in decreasing order of frequency are the appendix, ileum, and rectum. These tumors may cause carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by cutaneous flushing, sweating, bronchospasm, colicky abdominal pain, diarrhea, and right-sided cardiac valvular fibrosis.

Immunohistochemical (IHC) markers for carcinoid tumors are:

  • Neuron-specific enolase
  • Synaptophysin
  • Chromogranin A
  • Leu 7

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with complaints of headache, projectile vomiting, and blurring of vision. CT scan shows a mass lesion in the posterior cranial fossa. His medical records are unremarkable, except for a family history of colon cancer in three of his relatives. What is the most probable syndrome that this patient has?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the family history of colon cancer point to the diagnosis of Turcot syndrome. 

Turcot syndrome is a rare hereditary disorder clinically characterized by the occurrence of primary tumors of the colon and the central nervous system.

Two types of tumors are seen in Turcot syndrome. The first is characterized by childhood cerebellar medulloblastoma caused by mutations in the APC gene. The second type is characterized by gliomas, particularly glioblastoma multiforme, arising in both children and adults and is related to mismatch repair gene mutations.

Familial carcinoma syndromes and the common malignancies associated with them:

  •  Gorlin syndrome: Medulloblastoma and multiple early-onset basal cell carcinomas
  •  Lynch syndrome: Gastrointestinal and genito-urinary tumors and rarely gliomas in the brain
  •  Neurofibromatosis: Schwannoma
